original: yate svāhā dhāvate svāhoddrāvāya svāhoddrutāya svāhā śūkārāya svāhā śūkṛtāya svāhā niṣaṇāya svāhotthitāya svāhā javāya svāhā balāya svāhā vivartamānāya svāhā vivṛttāya svāhā vidhūnvānāya svāhā vidhūtāya svāhā śuśrūṣamāṇāya svāhā śṛṇvate svāhekṣamāṇāya svāhekṣitāya svāhā vīkṣitāya svāhā nimeṣāya svāhā yad atti tasmai svāhā yat pibati tasmai svāhā yan mūtraṃ karoti tasmai svāhā kurvate svāhā kṛtāya svāhā //
analyzed: yate svāhā dhāvate svāhā uddrāvāya svāhā uddrutāya svāhā śūkārāya svāhā śūkṛtāya svāhā niṣaṇāya svāhā utthitāya svāhā javāya svāhā balāya svāhā vivartamānāya svāhā vivṛttāya svāhā vidhūnvānāya svāhā vidhūtāya svāhā śuśrūṣamāṇāya svāhā śṛṇvate svāhā īkṣamāṇāya svāhā īkṣitāya svāhā vīkṣitāya svāhā nimeṣāya svāhā yat atti tasmai svāhā yat pibati tasmai svāhā yat mūtram karoti tasmai svāhā kurvate svā
translated: To him who hastens, Hail! To him who runs, Hail! To him who has run, Hail! To him who neighs, Hail! To him who has neighed, Hail! To him who sits down, Hail! To him who rises, Hail! To him who has speed, Hail! To him who has strength, Hail! To him who turns round, Hail! To him who has turned round, Hail! To him who shakes himself, Hail! To him who has shaken himself, Hail! To him who listens, Hail! To him who hears, Hail! To him who looks, Hail! To him who has looked, Hail! To him who has been looked at, Hail! To him who winks, Hail! To him who eats, Hail! To him who drinks, Hail! To him who makes water, Hail! To him who is making, Hail! To him who has made, Hail!🔽That excellent glory of Savitar the God, may we meditate,

original: tat savitur vareṇyaṃ bhargo devasya dhīmahi / dhiyo yo naḥ pracodayat //
analyzed: tat savituḥ vareṇyam bhargaḥ devasya dhīmahi dhiyaḥ yaḥ naḥ pracodayat
translated: That he may stimulate our mental power.🔽With hands of gold I call on Savitar to aid,

original: hiraṇyapāṇim ūtaye savitāram upa hvaye / sa cettā devatā padam //🔽devasya cetato mahīṃ pra savitur havāmahe / sumatim satyarādhasam //
analyzed: hiraṇya pāṇim ūtaye savitāram upa hvaye    sa cettā devatā padam  devasya cetataḥ mahīm pra savituḥ havāmahe     sumatim satya rādhasam
translated: He who discerns the place of the deity.🔽The wide dominion of the God who discerns,🔽We invoke of Savitar, whose bounty is true.🔽The good praise, the increaser of good thoughts, the gift of Savitar we implore,

original: suṣṭutim sumatīvṛdho rātim savitur īmahe / pra devāya matīvide //
analyzed: suṣṭutim sumatīvṛdhaḥ rātim savituḥ īmahe    pra devāya matī vide
translated: The God who discerns the thought.

original: rātim satpatiṃ mahe savitāram upa hvaye / āsavaṃ devavītaye //
analyzed: rātim sat patim mahe savitāram upa hvaye    āsavam deva vītaye
translated: I call on Savitar the Lord of bounty, the great, to give us what shall last for ever,

original: devasya savitur matim āsavaṃ viśvadevyam / dhiyā bhagaṃ manāmahe //
analyzed: devasya savituḥ matim āsavam viśvadevyam    dhiyā bhagam manāmahe
translated: The inspiration of the God Savitar, the all-god's inspiration, with our thought we meditate on Bhaga.

original: agnim stomena bodhaya samidhāno amartyam / havyā deveṣu no dadhat //
analyzed: agnim stomena bodhaya samidhānaḥ amartyam   havyā deveṣu naḥ dadhat
translated: Awaken Agni with the hymn, the immortal, kindled, who shall bring our offerings to the Gods.

original: sa havyavāḍ amartya uśig dūtaś canohitaḥ / agnir dhiyā sam ṛṇvati //
analyzed: sa havyavāṭ amartyaḥ uśij dūtaḥ canohitaḥ    agniḥ dhiyā sam ṛṇvati
translated: He, the immortal bearer of our gifts, the priest, the envoy, ever prompt to hear, Agni, with thought shall win us wealth.

original: agniṃ dūtaṃ puro dadhe havyavāham upa bruve / devām ā sādayād iha //🔽ajījano hi pavamāna sūryaṃ vidhāre śakmanā payaḥ / gojīrayā ramhamāṇaḥ purandhyā //
analyzed: agnim dūtam puras dadhe havyavāham upa bruve    devām ā sādayāt iha  ajījanaḥ hi pavamāna sūryam vidhāre śakmanā payaḥ    go jīrayā ramhamāṇaḥ purandhyā
translated: I place before me Agni as my envoy, I call the bearer of our gifts to worship. Here let him seat the Gods.🔽For thou, O Pavamâna, hast generated Sûrya, the sap with power to hold in the two bowls, rejoicing in the milk, in the young maiden.

original: vibhūr mātrā prabhūḥ pitrāśvo 'si hayo 'sy atyo 'si mayo 'sy arvāsi saptir asi vājy asi vṛṣāsi nṛmaṇā asi / yayur nāmāsi śiśur nāmāsy ādityānāṃ patvānv ihi //
analyzed: vibhūḥ mātrā prabhūḥ pitrā aśvaḥ si hayaḥ si atyaḥ si mayaḥ si  / arvā asi saptiḥ asi vājī asi vṛṣā asi nṛmaṇāḥ asi    yayuḥ nāma asi śiśuḥ nāma asi ādityānām patvā anu ihi
translated: Thou art the horse, thou art the courser, thou art the racer, thou art the courser, thou art the steed, thou art the strong one, thou art the man's delight. Thou art the horse named Yayu, thou art the horse named Child. Go to the place of the Âdityas.

original: devā āśāpālā etaṃ devebhyo 'śvaṃ medhāya prokṣitam rakṣat / iha rantiḥ / iha ramatām / iha dhṛtiḥ / iha svadhṛtiḥ svāhā //
analyzed: devāḥ āśā pālāḥ etam devebhyaḥ śvam medhāya prokṣitam rakṣat
translated: Ye guardians of desire, protect this horse for the Gods, sprinkled for the sacrifice. Here is delight, here let him take delight. Here is support, here is self-support. All hail!

original: kāya svāhā kasmai svāhā katamasmai svāhā svāhādhim ādhītāya svāhā manaḥ prajāpataye svāhācittaṃ vijñātāyādityai svāhādityai mahyai svāhādityai sumṛḍīkāyai svāhā sarasvatyai svāhā sarasvatyai pāvakāyai svāhā sarasvatyai bṛhatyai svāhā pūṣṇe svāhā pūṣṇe prapathyāya svāhā pūṣṇe naraṃdhiṣāya svāhā tvaṣṭre svāhā tvaṣṭre turīpāya svāhā tvaṣṭre pururūpāya svāhā viṣṇave svāhā viṣṇave nibhūyapāya svāhā viṣṇave śipiviṣṭāya svāhā //
analyzed: kāya svāhā kasmai svāhā katamasmai svāhā svāhā ādhim ādhītāya svāhā manaḥ prajāpataye svāhā acittam vijñātāya adityai svāhā adityai mahyai svāhā adityai su mṛḍīkāyai svāhā sarasvatyai svāhā sarasvatyai pāvakāyai svāhā sarasvatyai bṛhatyai svāhā pūṣṇe svāhā pūṣṇe prapathyāya svāhā pūṣṇe naraṃdhiṣāya svāhā tvaṣṭre svāhā tvaṣṭre turīpāya svāhā tvaṣṭre puru rūpāya svāhā viṣṇave svāhā viṣṇave nibhūyapāya sv
translated: To the body hail! To whom hail! To which (deity) hail! To the one who has laid the foundation hail! To the mind hail! To Prajâpati hail! To the thought hail! To the knowing Âditya hail! To Âditya the gracious hail! To Âditya the very gracious hail! To Sarasvatî hail! To Sarasvatî the pure hail! To Sarasvatî the great hail! To Pûshan hail! To Pûshan the wayfarer hail! To Pûshan the finder of men hail! To Tvashtar hail! To Tvashtar the all-impelling hail! To Tvashtar the multiform hail! To Vishnu hail! To Vishnu the subduer hail! To Vishnu the pierced hail!

original: viśvo devasya netur marto vurīta sakhyam / viśvo rāya iṣudhyati dyumnaṃ vṛṇīta puṣyase svāhā //
analyzed: viśvaḥ devasya netuḥ martaḥ vurīta sakhyam   viśvaḥ rāyaḥ iṣudhyati dyumnam vṛṇīta puṣyase svāhā
translated: Let every mortal man be friendly with the leader of the Gods. Every one longs for wealth: choose ye splendour that ye may prosper. All-hail!

original: ā brahman brāhmaṇo brahmavarcasī jāyatām ā rāṣṭre rājanyaḥ śūra iṣavyo 'tivyādhī mahāratho jāyatāṃ dogdhrī dhenur voḍhānaḍvān āśuḥ saptiḥ puraṃdhir yoṣā jiṣṇū ratheṣṭhāḥ sabheyo yuvāsya yajamānasya vīro jāyatāṃ nikāmenikāme naḥ parjanyo varṣatu phalavatyo na oṣadhayaḥ pacyantāṃ yogakṣemo naḥ kalpatām //
analyzed: ā brahman brāhmaṇaḥ brahmavarcasī jāyatām ā rāṣṭre rājanyaḥ śūraḥ iṣavyaḥ tivyādhī mahā rathaḥ jāyatām dogdhrī dhenuḥ voḍhā anaḍvān āśuḥ saptiḥ puraṃdhiḥ yoṣā jiṣṇuḥ ratheṣṭhāḥ sabheyaḥ yuvā asya yajamānasya vīraḥ jāyatām nikāmenikāme naḥ parjanyaḥ varṣatu phalavatyaḥ naḥ oṣadhayaḥ pacyantām yogakṣemaḥ naḥ kalpatām
translated: Let the Brahman be born with spiritual lustre, O Brahman; let the Kshatriya be born in the kingdom, a hero, a marksman, a long-distance shooter, a great warrior; let the milch cow be born, the draught ox, the swift horse, the maiden wife, the victorious charioteer, the young man fit for the assembly; let the sacrificer's hero be born. Let Parjanya rain for us according to our desire. Let the plants ripen with fruit. Let our acquisition and preservation be secured.

original: prāṇāya svāhāpānāya svāhā vyānāya svāhā cakṣuṣe svāhā śrotrāya svāhā vāce svāhā manase svāhā //
analyzed: prāṇāya svāhā apānāya svāhā vyānāya svāhā cakṣuṣe svāhā śrotrāya svāhā vāce svāhā manase svāhā
translated: To the out-breath Svâhâ! To the through-breath Svâhâ! To the up-breath Svâhâ! To the eye Svâhâ! To the ear Svâhâ! To speech Svâhâ! To the mind Svâhâ!

original: prācyai diśe svāhārvācyai diśe svāhā dakṣiṇāyai diśe svāhārvācyai diśe svāhā pratīcyai diśe svāhārvācyai diśe svāhodīcyai diśe svāhārvācyai diśe svāhordhvāyai diśe svāhārvācyai diśe svāhāvācyai diśe svāhārvācyai diśe svāhā //
analyzed: prācyai diśe svāhā arvācyai diśe svāhā dakṣiṇāyai diśe svāhā arvācyai diśe svāhā pratīcyai diśe svāhā arvācyai diśe svāhā udīcyai diśe svāhā arvācyai diśe svāhā ūrdhvāyai diśe svāhā arvācyai diśe svāhā avācyai diśe svāhā arvācyai diśe svāhā
translated: To the eastern region Svâhâ! To the intermediate region Svâhâ! To the southern region Svâhâ! To the intermediate region Svâhâ! To the western region Svâhâ! To the intermediate region Svâhâ! To the northern region Svâhâ! To the intermediate region Svâhâ! To the upper region Svâhâ! To the intermediate region Svâhâ! To the intermediate region Svâhâ! To the intermediate region Svâhâ!

original: adbhyaḥ svāhā vārbhyaḥ svāhodakāya svāhā tiṣṭhantībhyaḥ svāhā sravantībhyaḥ svāhā syandamānābhyaḥ svāhā kūpyābhyaḥ svāhā sūdyābhyaḥ svāhā dhāryābhyaḥ svāhārṇavāya svāhā samudrāya svāhā sarirāya svāhā //🔽vātāya svāhā dhūmāya svāhābhrāya svāhā meghāya svāhā vidyotamānāya svāhā stanayate svāhāvasphūrjate svāhā varṣate svāhāvavarṣate svāhodraṃ varṣate svāhā śīghraṃ varṣate svāhodgṛhṇate svāhodgṛhītāya svāhā pruṣṇate svāhā śīkāyate svāhā pruṣvābhyaḥ svāhā hrādunībhyaḥ svāhā nīhārāya svāhā //
analyzed: adbhyaḥ svāhā vārbhyaḥ svāhā udakāya svāhā tiṣṭhantībhyaḥ svāhā sravantībhyaḥ svāhā syandamānābhyaḥ svāhā kūpyābhyaḥ svāhā sūdyābhyaḥ svāhā dhāryābhyaḥ svāhā arṇavāya svāhā samudrāya svāhā sarirāya svāhā  vātāya svāhā dhūmāya svāhā abhrāya svāhā meghāya svāhā vidyotamānāya svāhā stanayate svāhā avasphūrjate svāhā varṣate svāhā avavarṣate svāhā udram varṣate svāhā śīghram varṣate svāhā udgṛhṇate svāhā udgṛhītāya svāhā pruṣṇate svāhā śīkāyate svāhā pruṣvābhyaḥ svāhā hrādunībhyaḥ svāhā nīhārāya svāhā
translated: To the waters hail! To the watery hail! To the waters hail! To the standing hail! To the flowing hail! To the running hail! To the well-waters hail! To the waters of the pool hail! To the waters of the tank hail! To the ocean hail! To the sea hail! To the river hail!🔽To the wind hail! To the smoke hail! To the cloud hail! To the rain-cloud hail! To the lightning hail! To the thunder hail! To the rain hail! To the non-rain hail! To the slow rain hail! To the quick rain hail! To the cloud that takes up hail! To the cloud that has taken up hail hail! To the cloud that rains hail! To the cloud that is about to rain hail! To the clouds hail! To the mist hail! To the dew hail!

original: agnaye svāhā somāya svāhendrāya svāhā pṛthivyai svāhāntarikṣāya svāhā dive svāhā digbhyaḥ svāhāśābhyaḥ svāhorvyai diśe svāhārvācyai diśe svāhā //
analyzed: agnaye svāhā somāya svāhā indrāya svāhā pṛthivyai svāhā antarikṣāya svāhā dive svāhā digbhyaḥ svāhā āśābhyaḥ svāhā urvyai diśe svāhā arvācyai diśe svāhā
translated: To Agni hail! To Soma hail! To Indra hail! To the earth hail! To the atmosphere hail! To the sky hail! To the quarters hail! To the intermediate quarters hail! To the downward-looking quarter hail! To the upward-looking quarter hail!

original: nakṣatrebhyaḥ svāhā nakṣatriyebhyaḥ svāhāhorātrebhyaḥ svāhārdhamāsebhyaḥ svāhā māsebnhyaḥ svāhā ṛtubhyaḥ svāhārtavebhyaḥ svāhā saṃvatsarāya svāhā dyāvāpṛthivībhyām svāhā candrāya svāhā sūryāya svāhā raśmibhyaḥ svāhā vasubhyaḥ svāhā rudrebhyaḥ svāhādityebhyaḥ svāhā marudbhyaḥ svāhā viśvebhyo devebhyaḥ svāhā mūlebhyaḥ svāhā śākhābhyaḥ svāhā vanaspatibhyaḥ svāhā puṣpebhyaḥ svāhā phalebhyaḥ svāhauṣadhībhyaḥ svāhā //
analyzed: nakṣatrebhyaḥ svāhā nakṣatriyebhyaḥ svāhā ahar rātrebhyaḥ svāhā ardha māsebhyaḥ svāhā māsebnhyaḥ svāhā ṛtubhyaḥ svāhā ārtavebhyaḥ svāhā saṃvatsarāya svāhā dyāvāpṛthivībhyām svāhā candrāya svāhā sūryāya svāhā raśmibhyaḥ svāhā vasubhyaḥ svāhā rudrebhyaḥ svāhā ādityebhyaḥ svāhā marudbhyaḥ svāhā viśvebhyaḥ devebhyaḥ svāhā mūlebhyaḥ svāhā śākhābhyaḥ svāhā vanaspatibhyaḥ svāhā puṣpebhyaḥ svāhā phalebhya
translated: To the Nakshatras hail! To the Nakshatriya (stars) hail! To the days and nights hail! To the half-months hail! To the months hail! To the seasons hail! To the periods of time hail! To the year hail! To Heaven and Earth hail! To the Moon hail! To the Sun hail! To the rays hail! To the Vasus hail! To the Rudras hail! To the Âdityas hail! To the Maruts hail! To the All-Gods hail! To the roots hail! To the branches hail! To the trees hail! To the flowers hail! To the fruits hail! To the plants hail!

original: pṛthivyai svāhāntarikṣāya svāhā dive svāhā sūryāya svāhā candrāya svāhā nakṣatrebhyaḥ svāhādbhyaḥ svāhauṣadhībhyaḥ svāhā vanaspatibhyaḥ svāhā pariplavebhyaḥ svāhā carācarebhyaḥ svāhā sarīsṛpebhyaḥ svāhā //
analyzed: pṛthivyai svāhā antarikṣāya svāhā dive svāhā sūryāya svāhā candrāya svāhā nakṣatrebhyaḥ svāhā adbhyaḥ svāhā oṣadhībhyaḥ svāhā vanaspatibhyaḥ svāhā pariplavebhyaḥ svāhā carācarebhyaḥ svāhā sarīsṛpebhyaḥ svāhā
translated: To Earth hail! To Firmament hail! To Heaven hail! To the Sun hail! To the Moon hail! To the Nakshatras hail! To the waters hail! To the plants hail! To the trees hail! To the creeping things hail! To the moving and unmoving hail! To the crawling things hail!

original: asave svāhā vasave svāhā vibhuve svāhā vivasvate svāhā gaṇaśriye svāhā gaṇapataye svāhābhibhuve svāhādhipataye svāhā śūṣāya svāhā samsarpāya svāhā candrāya svāhā jyotiṣe svāhā malimlucāya svāhā divā patayate svāhā //🔽madhave svāhā mādhavāya svāhā śukrāya svāhā śucaye svāhā nabhase svāhā nabhasyāya svāhāheṣāya svāhorjāya svāhā sahase svāhā sahasyāya svāhā tapase svāhā tapasyāya svāhāmhasaspataye svāhā //
analyzed: asave svāhā vasave svāhā vibhuve svāhā vivasvate svāhā gaṇa śriye svāhā gaṇapataye svāhā abhibhuve svāhā adhipataye svāhā śūṣāya svāhā samsarpāya svāhā candrāya svāhā jyotiṣe svāhā malimlucāya svāhā divā patayate svāhā  madhave svāhā mādhavāya svāhā śukrāya svāhā śucaye svāhā nabhase svāhā nabhasyāya svāhā aha iṣāya svāhā ūrjāya svāhā sahase svāhā sahasyāya svāhā tapase svāhā tapasyāya svāhā amhasaspataye svāhā
translated: To Asava hail! To Vasava hail! To Vibhu hail! To Vivasvat hail! To the glory of the host hail! To the lord of the host hail! To the overlord hail! To the lord hail! To Sûshâ hail! To Samsarpa hail! To Chandra hail! To Jyotish hail! To Malimlucha hail! To the lord of the day hail!🔽To Madhu hail! To Mâdhava hail! To Shukra hail! To Shukra hail! To Nabhas hail! To Nabhasya hail! To Heisha hail! To Urja hail! To Sahah hail! To Sahayya hail! To Tapas hail! To Tapasya hail! To the lord of Amhasa hail!

original: vājāya svāhā prasavāya svāhāpijāya svāhā kratave svāhā svaḥ svāhā mūrdhne svāhā vyaśnuvine svāhāntyāya svāhāntyāya bhauvanāya svāhā bhuvanasya pataye svāhādhipataye svāhā prajāpataye svāhā //
analyzed: vājāya svāhā prasavāya svāhā apijāya svāhā kratave svāhā svar svāhā mūrdhne svāhā vyaśnuvine svāhā antyāya svāhā antyāya bhauvanāya svāhā bhuvanasya pataye svāhā adhipataye svāhā prajāpataye svāhā
translated: To Vâja hail! To Prasava hail! To Apîja hail! To Kratu hail! To Svah hail! To the head hail! To the all-pervading hail! To the last hail! To the last lord of the world hail! To the lord of the world hail! To the overlord hail! To Prajâpati hail!

original: āyur yajñena kalpatām svāhā prāṇo yajñena kalpatām svāhāpāno yajñena kalpatām svāhā vyāno yajñena kalpatām svāhodāno yajñena kalpatām svāhā samāno yajñena kalpatām svāhā cakṣur yajñena kalpatām svāhā śrotraṃ yajñena kalpatām svāhā vāg yajñena kalpatām svāhā mano yajñena kalpatām svāhātmā yajñena kalpatām svāhā brahmā yajñena kalpatām svāhā jyotir yajñena kalpatām svāhā svar yajñena kalpatām svāhā pṛṣṭhaṃ yajñena kalpatām svāhā yajño yajñena kalpatām svāhā //
analyzed: āyuḥ yajñena kalpatām svāhā prāṇaḥ yajñena kalpatām svāhā apānaḥ yajñena kalpatām svāhā vyānaḥ yajñena kalpatām svāhā udānaḥ yajñena kalpatām svāhā samānaḥ yajñena kalpatām svāhā cakṣuḥ yajñena kalpatām svāhā śrotram yajñena kalpatām svāhā vāc yajñena kalpatām svāhā manaḥ yajñena kalpatām svāhā ātmā yajñena kalpatām svāhā brahmā yajñena kalpatām svāhā jyotiḥ yajñena kalpatām svāhā svar yajñena kalpatām svāhā pṛṣṭ
translated: May life be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May expiration be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May inspiration be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May cross-breathing be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May upward breathing be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May through-breathing be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May the eye be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May the ear be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May speech be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May the mind be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May the self be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May Brahman be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May light be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May heaven be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May the back be perfected by the sacrifice, hail! May the sacrifice be perfected by the sacrifice, hail!

original: ekasmai svāhā dvābhyām svāhā śatāya svāhaikaśatāya svāhā vyuṣṭyai svāhā svargāya svāhā //
analyzed: ekasmai svāhā dvābhyām svāhā śatāya svāhā ekaśatāya svāhā vyuṣṭyai svāhā svargāya svāhā
translated: To the one, hail! To the two, hail! To the hundred, hail! To the hundred and one, hail! To the dawn, hail! To heaven, hail!

original: hiraṇyagarbhaḥ sam avartatāgre bhūtasya jātaḥ patir eka āsīt / sa dādhāra pṛthivīṃ dyām utemāṃ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema //
analyzed: hiraṇya garbhaḥ sam avartata agre bhūtasya jātaḥ patiḥ ekaḥ āsīt    sa dādhāra pṛthivīm dyām uta imām kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
translated: Hiranyagarbha, in the beginning of creation, was born, the one Lord of all created beings. He supports this earth and the sky. To that God we offer our oblations.

original: upayāmagṛhīto 'si prajāpataye tvā juṣṭaṃ gṛhṇāmi / eṣa te yoniḥ sūryas te mahimā / yas te 'hant saṃvatsare mahimā saṃbabhūva yas te vāyāv antarikṣe mahimā saṃbabhūva yas te divi sūrye mahimā saṃbabhūva tasmai te mahimne prajāpataye svāhā devebhyaḥ //
analyzed: upayāma gṛhītā u si prajāpataye tvā juṣṭam gṛhṇāmi    eṣa te yoniḥ sūryaḥ te mahimā   yaḥ te han saṃvatsare mahimā saṃbabhūva yaḥ te vāyau antarikṣe mahimā saṃbabhūva yaḥ te divi sūrye mahimā saṃbabhūva tasmai te mahimne prajāpataye svāhā devebhyaḥ
translated: Thou art taken with a support. I take thee dear to Prajâpati. This is thy womb: the Sun is thy greatness. The greatness that hath been in thee in the year, the greatness that hath been in thee in the wind, in the atmosphere, the greatness that hath been in thee in the heaven, in the Sun, to that greatness of thine, to Prajâpati, All-hail to the Gods!

original: yaḥ prāṇato nimiṣato mahitvaika id rājā jagato babhūva / ya īśe asya dvipadaś catuṣpadaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema //
analyzed: yaḥ prāṇataḥ nimiṣataḥ mahitvā ekaḥ id rājā jagataḥ babhūva    yaḥ īśe asya dvipadaḥ catuṣpadaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
translated: He who, in might, is King of all that moves and all that moves not, who alone is the King of the world, who is Lord of this biped and quadruped, to what God shall we offer our oblation?

original: upayāmagṛhīto 'si prajāpataye tvā juṣṭaṃ gṛhṇāmi / eṣa te yoniś candras te mahimā / yas te rātrau saṃvatsare mahimā saṃbabhūva yas te pṛthivyām agnau mahimā saṃbabhūva yas te nakṣatreṣu candramasi mahimā saṃbabhūva tasmai te mahimne prajāpataye devebhyaḥ svāhā //
analyzed: upayāma gṛhītā u si prajāpataye tvā juṣṭam gṛhṇāmi    eṣa te yoniḥ candraḥ te mahimā   yaḥ te rātrau saṃvatsare mahimā saṃbabhūva yaḥ te pṛthivyām agnau mahimā saṃbabhūva yaḥ te nakṣatreṣu candramasi mahimā saṃbabhūva  / tasmai te mahimne prajāpataye devebhyaḥ svāhā
translated: Thou art taken with a support. I take thee dear to Prajâpati. This is thy womb: the Moon is thy greatness. The greatness that hath been in thee in the night, in the year, the greatness that hath been in thee in the earth, in the fire, the greatness that hath been in thee in the stars, in the moon, to that greatness of thine, to Prajâpati, to the Gods, All-hail!

original: yuñjanti bradhnam aruṣaṃ carantaṃ pari tasthuṣaḥ / rocante rocanā divi //
analyzed: yuñjanti bradhnam aruṣam carantam pari tasthuṣaḥ   rocante rocanā divi
translated: They yoke the ruddy one, the moving one, the one who stands around, the one who is above. The lights shine in the sky.

original: yuñjanty asya kāmyā harī vipakṣasā rathe / śoṇā dhṛṣṇū nṛsāhasā //
analyzed: yuñjanti asya kāmyā harī vipakṣasā rathe   śoṇā dhṛṣṇū nṛ sāhasā
translated: They yoke his desirable tawny horses on the two wings of the chariot, the red ones, the bold ones, the conquerors of men.

original: yad vāto apo aganīgan priyām indrasya tanvam / etam stotar anena pathā punar aśvam ā vartayāsi naḥ //
analyzed: yat vātaḥ apaḥ aganīgan priyām indrasya tanvam     etam stotar anena pathā punar aśvam ā vartayāsi naḥ
translated: When the wind has gone to the waters, the dear body of Indra, O worshipper, by this path bring back to us the horse.

original: vasavas tvāñjantu gāyatreṇa chandasā / rudrās tvāñjantu traiṣṭubhena chandasā / ādityās tvāñjantu jāgatena chandasā / bhūr bhuvaḥ svar yavye gavya etad annam atta devā etad annam addhi prajāpate //
analyzed: vasavaḥ tvā añjantu gāyatreṇa chandasā   rudrāḥ tvā añjantu traiṣṭubhena chandasā   ādityāḥ tvā añjantu jāgatena chandasā   bhūḥ bhuvaḥ svar   yavye gavye etat annam atta devāḥ etat annam addhi prajāpate
translated: May the Vasus anoint you with the Gayatri meter. May the Rudras anoint you with the Tristubh meter. May the Adityas anoint you with the Jagati meter. Earth, atmosphere, heaven, barley, cow, eat this food, O gods, eat this food, O Prajapati.

original: kaḥ svid ekākī carati ka u svij jāyate punaḥ / kim svid dhimasya bheṣajaṃ kim v āvapanaṃ mahat //
analyzed: kaḥ svid ekākī carati kaḥ u svid jāyate punar   kim svid him asya bheṣajam kim u āvapanam mahat
translated: Who indeed moves alone? Who is born again? What is the remedy for cold? And what is the great covering?

original: sūrya ekākī carati candramā jāyate punaḥ / agnir dhimasya bheṣajaṃ bhūmir āvapanaṃ mahat //
analyzed: sūryaḥ ekākī carati candramāḥ jāyate punar   agniḥ bheṣajam bhūmiḥ āvapanam mahat
translated: The sun moves alone. The moon is born again. Fire is the remedy for cold. The earth is the great covering.

original: kā svid āsīt pūrvacittiḥ kim svid āsīd bṛhad vayaḥ / kā svid āsīt pilippilā kā svid āsīt piśaṅgilā //
analyzed: kā svid āsīt pūrvacittiḥ kim svid āsīt bṛhat vayaḥ   kā svid āsīt pilippilā kā svid āsīt piśaṅgilā
translated: What was the first thought? What was the great age? What was the pilpipila? What was the pisangila?

original: dyaur āsīt pūrvacittiḥ aśva āsīd bṛhad vayaḥ / avir āsīt pilippilā rātrir āsīt piśaṅgilā //
analyzed: dyauḥ āsīt pūrvacittiḥ aśvaḥ āsīt bṛhat vayaḥ   aviḥ āsīt pilippilā rātriḥ āsīt piśaṅgilā
translated: The sky was the first thought. The horse was the great age. The sheep was the pilpipila. The night was the pisangila.

original: vāyuṣ ṭvā pacatair avatu / asitagrīvaś chāgaiḥ / nyagrodhaś camasaiḥ / śalmalir vṛddhyā / eṣa sya rāthyo vṛṣā / paḍbhiś caturbhir ed agan / brahmākṛṣṇaś ca no 'vatu / namo 'gnaye //
analyzed: vāyuḥ tvā pacataiḥ avatu    asita grīvaḥ chāgaiḥ   nyagrodhaḥ camasaiḥ   śalmaliḥ vṛddhyā   eṣa sya rāthyaḥ vṛṣā   paḍbhiḥ caturbhiḥ ā id agan    brahmā akṛṣṇaḥ ca naḥ vatu    namaḥ gnaye
translated: May Vayu protect you with the cooked, Asitagriva with the goats, the Nyagrodha with the bowls, the Shalmali with the growth. This is the chariot-horse, the bull, he has come with four feet. May Brahma and Krishna protect us. Homage to Agni.

original: samśito raśminā rathaḥ samśito raśminā hayaḥ / samśito apsv apsujā brahmā somapurogavaḥ //
analyzed: samśitaḥ raśminā rathaḥ samśitaḥ raśminā hayaḥ    samśitaḥ apsu apsujāḥ brahmā soma purogavaḥ
translated: The chariot is sharpened with the reins, the horse is sharpened with the reins, the water-born is sharpened in the waters, the Brahman with Soma in the lead.

original: svayaṃ vājims tanvaṃ kalpayasva svayaṃ yajasva svayaṃ juṣasva / mahimā te 'nyena na saṃnaśe //
analyzed: svayam vājim tanvam kalpayasva svayam yajasva svayam juṣasva    mahimā te nyena na saṃnaśe
translated: O horse, make your own body ready, offer yourself, enjoy yourself. Your greatness shall not be diminished by another.

original: na vā u etan mriyase na riṣyasi devām id eṣi pathibhiḥ sugebhiḥ / yatrāsate sukṛto yatra te yayus tatra tvā devaḥ savitā dadhātu //
analyzed: na vai u etat mriyase na riṣyasi devām id eṣi pathibhiḥ su gebhiḥ    yatra āsate su kṛtaḥ yatra te yayuḥ tatra tvā devaḥ savitā dadhātu
translated: You do not die, you are not injured, you go to the gods by the easy paths, to the place where the righteous dwell, to the place where they have gone. May the god Savita place you there.

original: agniḥ paśur āsīt tenāyajanta sa etaṃ lokam ajayad yasminn agniḥ sa te loko bhaviṣyati taṃ jeṣyasi pibaitā apaḥ / vāyuḥ paśur āsīt tenāyajanta sa etaṃ lokam ajayad yasmin vāyuḥ sa te loko bhaviṣyati taṃ jeṣyasi pibaitā apaḥ / sūryaḥ paśur āsīt tenāyajanta sa etaṃ lokam ajayad yasmint sūryaḥ sa te loko bhaviṣyati taṃ jeṣyasi pibaitā apaḥ //
analyzed: agniḥ paśuḥ āsīt tena ayajanta saḥ etam lokam ajayat yasmin agniḥ saḥ te lokaḥ bhaviṣyati tam jeṣyasi piba etāḥ apaḥ    vāyuḥ paśuḥ āsīt tena ayajanta saḥ etam lokam ajayat yasmin vāyuḥ sa te lokaḥ bhaviṣyati tam jeṣyasi piba etāḥ apaḥ    sūryaḥ paśuḥ āsīt tena ayajanta saḥ etam lokam ajayat yasmin sūryaḥ sa te lokaḥ bhaviṣyati tam jeṣyasi piba etāḥ apaḥ
translated: Agni was the victim: with him they sacrificed. He won that world in which is Agni. That world shall be thine: thou shalt win it. Drink these waters. Vâyu was the victim: with him they sacrificed. He won that world in which is Vâyu. That world shall be thine: thou shalt win it. Drink these waters. Sûrya was the victim: with him they sacrificed. He won that world in which is Sûrya. That world shall be thine: thou shalt win it. Drink these waters.

original: prāṇāya svāhā / apānāya svāhā / vyānāya svāhā ambe ambike 'mbālike na mā nayati kaś cana / sasasty aśvakaḥ subhadrikāṃ kāmpīlavāsinīm //
analyzed: prāṇāya svāhā   apānāya svāhā   vyānāya svāhā ambe ambike mbālike na mā nayati kaḥ cana   sasasti aśvakaḥ subhadrikām kāmpīla vāsinīm
translated: To expiration hail! To cross-breathing hail! To inspiration hail! O mother, O mother of all, O mother of the world, no one leads me away. The horse Sasa has coupled with the auspicious Kâmpîlavâsinî.

original: gaṇānāṃ tvā gaṇapatim havāmahe priyāṇāṃ tvā priyapatim havāmahe nidhīnāṃ tvā nidhipatim havāmahe vaso mama / āham ajāni garbhadham ā tvam ajāsi garbhadham //
analyzed: gaṇānām tvā gaṇa patim havāmahe priyāṇām tvā priya patim havāmahe nidhīnām tvā nidhi patim havāmahe vaso mama    ā aham ajāni garbha dham ā tvam ajāsi garbha dham
translated: Thee, the lord of troops, we invoke. Thee, the lord of dear ones, we invoke. Thee, the lord of treasures, we invoke, O Vasu. I have known the bearer of the embryo: thou hast become the bearer of the embryo.

original: tā ubhau caturaḥ padaḥ sampra sārayāva svarge loke prorṇuvāthāṃ vṛṣā vājī retodhā reto dadhātu //
analyzed: tau ubhau caturaḥ padaḥ sampra sārayāva svarge loke prorṇuvāthām vṛṣā vājī retaḥ dhāḥ retaḥ dadhātu
translated: You two, both of you, lead the four feet together. In the heavenly world, you two, both of you, spread out. The strong stallion, the seed-implanter, may he place seed.

original: utsakthyā ava gudaṃ dhehi sam añjiṃ cārayā vṛṣan / ya strīṇāṃ jīvabhojanaḥ //
analyzed: utsakthyāḥ ava gudam dhehi sam añjim cāraya vṛṣan   yaḥ strīṇām jīva bhojanaḥ
translated: Place the anus on the thigh, O bull, and make the penis straight, he who is the life-giver of women.

original: yakāsakau śakuntikāhalag iti vañcati / ā hanti gabhe paso nigalgalīti dhārakā //
analyzed: iti vañcati    ā hanti gabhe pasaḥ iti dhārakā
translated: The two who cough, the female bird, the one who clings to the throat, deceives. He strikes in the womb, the bolt, he falls down, the supporter.

original: yako 'sakau śakuntaka āhalag iti vañcati / vivakṣata iva te mukham adhvaryo mā nas tvam abhi bhāṣathāḥ //
analyzed: śakuntakaḥ iti vañcati      vivakṣate iva te mukham adhvaryo mā naḥ tvam abhi
translated: The two who cough, the female bird, the one who clings to the throat, deceives. Your mouth seems to be yawning, O Adhvaryu, do not speak to us.

original: mātā ca te pitā ca te 'graṃ vṛkṣasya rohataḥ / pratilāmīti te pitā gabhe muṣṭim atamsayat //
analyzed: mātā ca te pitā ca te gram vṛkṣasya rohataḥ    pratilāmi iti te pitā gabhe muṣṭim atamsayat
translated: Your mother and your father are the top of the tree when you climb. Your father, I think, stretched out his fist in the womb.

original: mātā ca te pitā ca te 'gre vṛkṣasya krīḍataḥ / vivakṣata iva te mukhaṃ brahman mā nas tvaṃ vado bahu //
analyzed: mātā ca te pitā ca te gre vṛkṣasya krīḍataḥ vivakṣate iva te mukham brahman mā naḥ tvam vadaḥ bahu
translated: Your mother and your father are the top of the tree when they play. Your mouth seems to be yawning, O Brahman, do not speak much to us.

original: ūrdhvam enām uc chrāpaya girau bhāram harann iva / athāsyai madhyam edhatām śīte vāte punann iva //
analyzed: ūrdhvam enām ud śrāpaya girau bhāram haran iva    atha asyai madhyam edhatām śīte vāte punan iva
translated: Lift her up as if carrying a load on a mountain, then let her middle be filled as if refreshing with a cold wind.

original: ūrdhvam enam uc chrāpaya girau bhāram harann iva / athāsya madhyam ejatu śīte vāte punann iva //
analyzed: ūrdhvam enam ud śrāpaya girau bhāram haran iva    atha asya madhyam ejatu śīte vāte punan iva
translated: Lift him up, as one who bears a load on the mountain. Then let his middle swell, as the cold wind blows, purifying him.🔽Whatever thick and solid flesh there is in her, which is to be cut away,

original: yad asyā amhubhedyāḥ kṛdhu sthūlam upātasat / muṣkāv asyā ejato gośaphe śakulāv iva //
analyzed: yat asyāḥ amhubhedyāḥ kṛdhu sthūlam upātasat    muṣkau asyāḥ ejataḥ go śaphe śakulau iva
translated: her thighs move like two fishes in a fish-trap.🔽When the gods have put into her the most beautiful, the most active,

original: yad devāso lalāmaguṃ pra viṣṭīminam āviṣuḥ / sakthnā dediśyate nārī satyasyākṣibhuvo yathā //🔽yad dhariṇo yavam atti na puṣṭaṃ paśu manyate / śūdrā yad aryajārā na poṣāya dhanāyati //
analyzed: yat devāsaḥ lalāmagum pra viṣṭīminam āviṣuḥ   / sakthnā dediśyate nārī satyasya akṣi bhuvaḥ yathā  yat hariṇaḥ yavam atti na puṣṭam paśu manyate   śūdrā yat arya jārā na poṣāya dhanāyati
translated: the woman is directed by her thighs, as if by the eyes of truth.🔽When the antelope eats the barley, he thinks it is not nourishing food. When the Śūdra is the paramour of an Ārya woman, he does not strive for prosperity.

original: yad dhariṇo yavam atti na puṣṭaṃ bahu manyate / śūdro yad aryāyai jāro na poṣam anu manyate //
analyzed: yat hariṇaḥ yavam atti na puṣṭam bahu manyate   śūdraḥ yat aryāyai jāraḥ na poṣam anu manyate
translated: When the antelope eats the barley, he thinks it is not nourishing food. When the Śūdra is the paramour of an Ārya woman, he does not strive for prosperity.

original: dadhikrāvṇo akāriṣaṃ jiṣṇor aśvasya vājinaḥ / surabhi no mukhā karat pra ṇa āyūmṣi tāriṣat //
analyzed: dadhikrāvṇaḥ akāriṣam jiṣṇoḥ aśvasya vājinaḥ    surabhi naḥ mukhā karat pra naḥ āyūmṣi tāriṣat
translated: I have praised Dadhikrāvan, the victorious, powerful horse. May he make our mouths fragrant and lead us to long life.🔽May the Gāyatrī, Triṣṭubh, Jagatī, Anuṣṭubh, Paṅkti,

original: gāyatrī triṣṭub jagaty anuṣṭup paṅktyā saha / bṛhaty uṣṇihā kakup sūcībhiḥ śamyantu tvā //
analyzed: gāyatrī triṣṭubh jagatī anuṣṭubh paṅktyā saha bṛhatī uṣṇihā kakubh sūcībhiḥ śamyantu tvā
translated: Bṛhatī, Uṣṇih, Kakup, and Sūcī meters pacify you.

original: dvipadā yāś catuṣpadās tripadā yāś ca ṣaṭpadāḥ / vicchandā yāś ca sacchandāḥ sūcībhiḥ śamyantu tvā //
analyzed: dvi padāḥ yāḥ catuṣpadāḥ tri padāḥ yāḥ ca ṣaṣ padāḥ   vicchandāḥ yāḥ ca sa chandāḥ sūcībhiḥ śamyantu tvā
translated: The two-footed and the four-footed, the three-footed and the six-footed, the disjointed and the well-jointed, may they appease thee with needles.

original: mahānāmnyo revatyo viśvā āśāḥ prahūvarīḥ / maighīr vidyuto vācaḥ sūcībhiḥ śamyantu tvā //
analyzed: mahānāmnyaḥ revatyaḥ viśvāḥ āśāḥ prahūvarīḥ    maighīḥ vidyutaḥ vācaḥ sūcībhiḥ śamyantu tvā
translated: The great-named, the prosperous, all the quarters, the loud-sounding, the rainy, the lightning, the voices, may they appease thee with needles.

original: nāryas te patnyo loma vi cinvantu manīṣayā / devānāṃ patnyo diśaḥ sūcībhiḥ śamyantu tvā //
analyzed: nāryaḥ te patnyaḥ loma vi cinvantu manīṣayā    devānām patnyaḥ diśaḥ sūcībhiḥ śamyantu tvā
translated: Thy wives are the women; let them disentangle thy hair with their thought. The quarters, the wives of the gods, may they appease thee with needles.

original: rajatā hariṇīḥ sīsā yujo yujyante karmabhiḥ / aśvasya vājinas tvaci simāḥ śamyantu śamyantīḥ //
analyzed: rajatāḥ hariṇīḥ sīsāḥ yujaḥ yujyante karmabhiḥ    aśvasya vājinaḥ tvaci simāḥ śamyantu śamyantīḥ
translated: The silver, the tawny, the lead, are yoked together by the rites. On the skin of the strong horse may the seams be appeased, the appeasing ones.

original: kuvid aṅga yavamanto vayaṃ cid yathā dānty anupūrvaṃ viyūya / ihehaiṣāṃ kṛṇuhi bhojanāni ye barhiṣo namaktiṃ yajanti //
analyzed: kuvid aṅga yavamantaḥ vayam cit yathā dānti anupūrvam viyūya    iha iha eṣām kṛṇuhi bhojanāni ye barhiṣaḥ namaktim yajanti
translated: O ye who have barley, even we, as they thresh in order, do thou scatter. Here, here make thou food for them who worship the bowing of the sacred grass.

original: kas tvā chyati kas tvā vi śāsti kas te gātrāṇi śamyati / ka u te śamitā kaviḥ //
analyzed: kaḥ tvā chyati kaḥ tvā vi śāsti kaḥ te gātrāṇi śamyati    kaḥ u te śamitā kaviḥ
translated: Who shaves thee? Who directs thee? Who appeases thy limbs? Who is thy appeasing sage?

original: ṛtavas tvā ṛtuthā parva śamitāro vi śāsatu / saṃvatsarasya tejasā śamībhiḥ śamyantu tvā //
analyzed: ṛtavaḥ tvā ṛtuthā parva śamitāraḥ vi śāsatu     saṃvatsarasya tejasā śamībhiḥ śamyantu tvā
translated: The seasons, in due season, the shapers, let them direct thy joints. With the splendour of the year, with the appeasers, let them appease thee with the appeasing ones.

original: ardhamāsāḥ parūmṣi te māsā ā chyantu śamyantaḥ / ahorātrāṇi maruto viliṣṭam sūdayantu te //🔽daivyā adhvaryavas tvā chyantu vi ca āsatu / gātrāṇi parvaśas te simāḥ kṛṇvantu śamyantīḥ //
analyzed: ardha māsāḥ parūmṣi te māsāḥ ā chyantu śamyantaḥ   ahorātrāṇi marutaḥ viliṣṭam sūdayantu te  daivyāḥ adhvaryavaḥ tvā chyantu vi ca āsatu  / gātrāṇi parvaśas te simāḥ kṛṇvantu śamyantīḥ
translated: The half-months are thy limbs, let them be healed by the healing ones. Let the days and nights, the Maruts, restore what is torn in thee.🔽Let the divine Adhvaryus heal thee and cut thee asunder. Let the healing ones make thy limbs in the joints with sutures.

original: dyaus te pṛthivy antarikṣaṃ vāyuś chidraṃ pṛṇātu te / sūyas te nakṣatraiḥ saha lokaṃ kṛṇotu sādhuyā //
analyzed: dyauḥ te pṛthivī antarikṣam vāyuḥ chidram pṛṇātu te   sūyaḥ te nakṣatraiḥ saha lokam kṛṇotu sādhuyā
translated: Let Dyaus, let Pṛthivī, let the atmosphere, let Vāyu fill the gap in thee. Let Sūrya make thy world with the stars in due order.

original: śaṃ te parebhyo gātrebhyaḥ śam astv avarebhyaḥ / śam asthabhyo majjabhyaḥ śam v astu tanvai tava //
analyzed: śam te parebhyaḥ gātrebhyaḥ śam astu avarebhyaḥ   śam asthabhyaḥ majjabhyaḥ śam u astu tanvai tava
translated: Good be to thee of thy higher limbs, good be to thee of thy lower limbs. Good be to thy bones and to thy marrow, good be to thy body.

original: kaḥ svid ekākī carati ka u svij jāyate punaḥ / kim svid dhimasya bheṣajaṃ kim v āvapanaṃ mahat //
analyzed: kaḥ svid ekākī carati kaḥ u svid jāyate punar   kim svid him asya bheṣajam kim u āvapanam mahat
translated: Who is it that walks alone? Who is it that is born again? What is the remedy for cold? What is the great covering?

original: sūrya ekākī carati candramā jāyate punaḥ / agnir dhimasya bheṣajaṃ bhūmir āvapanaṃ mahat //
analyzed: sūryaḥ ekākī carati candramāḥ jāyate punar   agniḥ bheṣajam bhūmiḥ āvapanam mahat
translated: The sun walks alone. The moon is born again. Fire is the remedy for cold. The earth is the great covering.

original: kim svit sūryasamaṃ jyotiḥ kim samudrasamam saraḥ / kim svit pṛthivyai varṣīyaḥ kasya mātrā na vidyate //
analyzed: kim svid sūrya samam jyotiḥ kim samudra samam saraḥ   kim svid pṛthivyai varṣīyaḥ kasya mātrā na vidyate
translated: What is the light equal to the sun? What is the lake equal to the ocean? What is greater than the earth? Whose measure is not known?

original: brahma sūryasamaṃ jyotir dyauḥ samudrasamam saraḥ / indraḥ pṛthivyai varṣīyān gos tu mātrā na vidyate //
analyzed: brahma sūrya samam jyotiḥ dyauḥ samudra samam saraḥ    indraḥ pṛthivyai varṣīyān goḥ tu mātrā na vidyate
translated: The Brahman is a light like the sun, the sky is a lake like the ocean, Indra is greater than the earth, but the cow has no measure.

original: pṛcchāmi tvā citaye devasakha yadi tvam atra manasā jagantha / yeṣu viṣṇus triṣu padeṣv eṣṭas teṣu viśvaṃ bhuvanam ā //
analyzed: pṛcchāmi tvā citaye deva sakha yadi tvam atra manasā jagantha    yeṣu viṣṇuḥ triṣu padeṣu eṣṭaḥ teṣu viśvam bhuvanam ā
translated: I ask you, O friend of the gods, to understand, if you have thought about this in your mind, in which of the three steps Vishnu is desired, in which the whole world is contained.

original: api teṣu triṣu padeṣv asmi yeṣu viśvaṃ bhuvanam āviveśa / sadyaḥ pary emi pṛthivīm uta dyām ekenāṅgena divo asya pṛṣṭham //
analyzed: api teṣu triṣu padeṣu asmi yeṣu viśvam bhuvanam āviveśa  / sadyas pari emi pṛthivīm uta dyām ekena aṅgena divaḥ asya pṛṣṭham
translated: I am indeed in those three steps, in which the whole world has entered. I quickly go around the earth and the sky with one part. The back of this heaven.

original: keṣv antaḥ puruṣa ā viveśa kāny antaḥ puruṣe arpitāni / etad brahmann upavalhāmasi tvā kim svin naḥ prati vocāsy atra //
analyzed: keṣu antar puruṣaḥ ā viveśa kāni antar puruṣe arpitāni    etat brahman upavalhāmasi tvā kim svid naḥ prati vocāsi atra
translated: In which of them has the man entered? Which of them are entrusted to the man? O Brahman, we are asking you this. What will you answer us about this?

original: pañcasv antaḥ puruṣa ā viveśa tāny antaḥ puruṣe arpitāni / etat tvātra pratimanvāno asmi na māyayā bhavasy uttaro mat //
analyzed: pañcasu antar puruṣaḥ ā viveśa tāni antar puruṣe arpitāni    etat tvā atra pratimanvānaḥ asmi na māyayā bhavasi uttaraḥ mat
translated: The man has entered into the five. They are entrusted to the man. I am thinking about this in my mind. Do not be above me through your magic, O Bhava.

original: kā svid āsīt pūrvacittiḥ kim svid āsīd bṛhad vayaḥ / kā svid āsīt pilippilā kā svid āsīt piśaṅgilā //
analyzed: kā svid āsīt pūrvacittiḥ kim svid āsīt bṛhat vayaḥ   kā svid āsīt pilippilā kā svid āsīt piśaṅgilā
translated: What was the first thought? What was the great age? What was the Pipilika? What was the Pishangila?

original: dyaur āsīt pūrvacittiḥ aśva āsīd bṛhad vayaḥ / avir āsīt pilippilā rātrir āsīt piśaṅgilā //
analyzed: dyauḥ āsīt pūrvacittiḥ aśvaḥ āsīt bṛhat vayaḥ   aviḥ āsīt pilippilā rātriḥ āsīt piśaṅgilā
translated: The sky was the first thought, the horse was the great life, the sheep was Pilippila, the night was Pishangila.

original: ka īm are piśaṃgilā ka īṃ kurupiśaṃgilā / ka īm āskandam arṣati ka īṃ panthāṃ vi sarpati //
analyzed: kaḥ īm are piśaṃgilā kaḥ īm kuru piśaṃgilā   kaḥ īm āskandam arṣati kaḥ īm panthām vi sarpati
translated: Who is the tawny one? Who is the dark-tawny one? Who rushes down the slope? Who spreads out the path?

original: ajāre piśaṃgilā śvāvit kurupiśaṃgilā / śaśa āskandam arṣaty ahiḥ panthāṃ vi sarpati //
analyzed: ajāre piśaṃgilā śvāvidh kuru piśaṃgilā    śaśaḥ āskandam arṣati ahiḥ panthām vi sarpati
translated: The sheep is the tawny one, the dog is the dark-tawny one. The hare rushes down the slope, the serpent spreads out the path.

original: katy asya viṣṭhāḥ katy akṣarāṇi kati homāsaḥ katidhā samiddhaḥ / yajñasya tvā vidathā pṛccham atra kati hotāra ṛtuśo yajanti //
analyzed: kati asya viṣṭhāḥ kati akṣarāṇi kati homāsaḥ katidhā samiddhaḥ    yajñasya tvā vidathā pṛccham atra kati hotāraḥ ṛtuśas yajanti
translated: How many are his portions? How many syllables? How many oblations? In how many ways is the fire kindled? I ask you about the ordinances of the sacrifice here. How many priests offer according to the seasons?

original: ṣaḍ asya viṣṭhāḥ śatam akṣarāṇy aśītir homāḥ samidho ha tisraḥ / yajñasya te vidathā pra bravīmi sapta hotāra ṛtuśo yajanti //
analyzed: ṣaḍ asya viṣṭhāḥ śatam akṣarāṇi aśītiḥ homāḥ samidhaḥ ha tisraḥ   yajñasya te vidathā pra bravīmi sapta hotāraḥ ṛtuśas yajanti
translated: Six are his portions, a hundred are the syllables, eighty are the oblations, and there are three kindling sticks. I tell you the ordinances of the sacrifice. Seven priests offer according to the seasons.

original: ko asya veda bhuvanasya nābhiṃ ko dyāvāpṛthivī antarikṣam / kaḥ sūryasya veda bṛhato janitraṃ ko veda candramasaṃ yatojāḥ //
analyzed: kaḥ asya veda bhuvanasya nābhim kaḥ dyāvāpṛthivī antarikṣam   kaḥ sūryasya veda bṛhataḥ janitram kaḥ veda candramasam yata ojāḥ
translated: Who knows the navel of this world? Who knows heaven, earth, and the atmosphere? Who knows the great sun's birthplace? Who knows the moon's origin?

original: vedāham asya bhuvanasya nābhiṃ veda dyāvāpṛthivī antarikṣam / veda sūryasya bṛhato janitraṃ atho veda candramasaṃ yatojāḥ //
analyzed: veda aham asya bhuvanasya nābhim veda dyāvāpṛthivī antarikṣam   veda sūryasya bṛhataḥ janitram atha u veda candramasam yata ojāḥ
translated: I know the navel of this world, I know heaven and earth and the atmosphere. I know the great birthplace of the sun, and also I know whence the moon was born.

original: pṛcchāmi tvā param antaṃ pṛthivyāḥ pṛcchāmi yatra bhuvanasya nābhiḥ / pṛcchāmi tvā vṛṣṇo aśvasya retaḥ pṛcchāmi vācaḥ paramaṃ vyoma //
analyzed: pṛcchāmi tvā param antam pṛthivyāḥ pṛcchāmi yatra bhuvanasya nābhiḥ  / pṛcchāmi tvā vṛṣṇaḥ aśvasya retaḥ pṛcchāmi vācaḥ paramam vyoma
translated: I ask thee of the farthest end of the earth, I ask where is the navel of the world. I ask of the seed of the strong horse, I ask of the highest sphere of speech.

original: iyaṃ vediḥ paro antaḥ pṛthivyā ayaṃ yajño yatra bhuvanasya nābhiḥ / ayam somo vṛṣṇo aśvasya retaḥ brahmāyaṃ vācaḥ paramaṃ vyoma //
analyzed: iyam vediḥ paraḥ antaḥ pṛthivyāḥ ayam yajñaḥ yatra bhuvanasya nābhiḥ   ayam somaḥ vṛṣṇaḥ aśvasya retaḥ brahmā ayam vācaḥ paramam vyoma
translated: This is the altar, the farthest end of the earth, this is the sacrifice where is the navel of the world. This is the seed of the strong horse, this Brahman is the highest sphere of speech.

original: subhūḥ svayambhūḥ prathamo 'ntar mahaty arṇave / dadhe ha garbham ṛtviyaṃ yato jātaḥ prajāpatiḥ //
analyzed: subhūḥ svayambhūḥ prathamaḥ ntar mahati arṇave    dadhe ha garbham ṛtviyam yatas jātaḥ prajāpatiḥ
translated: The good, self-existent one, the first in the great ocean, has placed the proper embryo, from which Prajapati was born.

original: hotā yakṣat prajāpatim somasya mahimnaḥ / juṣatāṃ pibatu somam hotar yaja //
analyzed: hotā yakṣat prajāpatim somasya mahimnaḥ   juṣatām pibatu somam hotar yaja
translated: The Hotar shall worship Prajapati, the greatness of Soma. May he accept and drink the Soma. O Hotar, perform the sacrifice.

original: prajāpate na tvad etāny anyo viśvā rūpāṇi pari tā babhūva / yatkāmās te juhumas tan no astu //
analyzed: prajāpate na tvat etāni anyaḥ viśvā rūpāṇi pari tā babhūva   yad kāmāḥ te juhumaḥ tat naḥ astu
translated: O Prajapati, none other than you has encompassed all these forms. Whatever desires we have in offering to you, may that be ours.

original: aśvas tūparo gomṛgas te prājāpatyāḥ kṛṣṇagrīva āgneyo rarāṭe purastāt sārasvatī meṣy adhastād dhanvor āśvināv adhorāmau bāhvoḥ saumapauṣṇaḥ śyāmo nābhyām sauryayāmau śvetaś ca kṛṣṇaś ca pārśvayos tvāṣṭrau lomaśasakthau sakthyor vāyavyaḥ śvetaḥ puccha indrāya svapasyāya vehad vaiṣṇavo vāmanaḥ //
analyzed: aśvaḥ tūparaḥ gomṛgaḥ te prājāpatyāḥ kṛṣṇa grīvaḥ āgneyaḥ rarāṭe purastāt sārasvatī meṣī adhastāt dhanvoḥ āśvinau adhorāmau bāhvoḥ sauma pauṣṇaḥ śyāmaḥ nābhyām saurya yāmau śvetaḥ ca kṛṣṇaḥ ca pārśvayoḥ tvāṣṭrau lomaśa sakthau sakthyoḥ vāyavyaḥ śvetaḥ pucche indrāya svapasyāya vehat vaiṣṇavaḥ vāmanaḥ
translated: The horse, the hornless goat, the Gayal, these are sacred to Prajapati. The black-necked (beast) is sacred to Agni. The female ass of Sarasvatî is under the shoulder-blade. The two with white backs, sacred to the Asvins, are on the fore-feet. The dark one, sacred to Soma and Pûshan, is on the navel. The white and the black, sacred to Sûrya and Yama, are on the sides. The two with hairy legs, sacred to Tvastr, are on the thighs. The white one, sacred to Vâyu, is on the tail. The dwarf, sacred to Vishnu, is for Indra to chew the cud.

original: rohito dhūmrarohitaḥ karkandhurohitas te saumyā babhrur aruṇababhruḥ śukababhrus te vāruṇāḥ śitirandhro 'nyataḥśitirandhraḥ samantaśitirandhras te sāvitrāḥ śitibāhur anyataḥśitibāhuḥ samantaśitibāhus te bārhaspatyāḥ pṛṣatī kṣudrapṛṣatī sthūlapṛṣatī tā maitrāvaruṇyaḥ //
analyzed: rohitaḥ dhūmrarohitaḥ karkandhurohitaḥ te saumyāḥ babhruḥ aruṇa babhruḥ śuka babhruḥ te vāruṇāḥ śitirandhraḥ nyatas śitirandhraḥ samantaśitirandhraḥ te sāvitrāḥ śitibāhuḥ anyatas śitibāhuḥ samantaśitibāhuḥ te bārhaspatyāḥ pṛṣatī kṣudrapṛṣatī sthūlapṛṣatī tāḥ maitrāvaruṇyaḥ
translated: The red, the smoke-red, the jujube-red, these are sacred to Soma. The brown, the red-brown, the parrot-brown, these are sacred to Varuna. The white-holed, the white-holed-on-one-side, the all-white-holed, these are sacred to Savitri. The white-armed, the white-armed-on-one-side, the all-white-armed, these are sacred to Brihaspati. The speckled, the little-speckled, the thick-speckled, these are sacred to Mitra and Varuna.

original: śuddhavālaḥ sarvaśuddhavālo maṇivālas ta āśvināḥ śyetaḥ śyetākṣo 'ruṇas te rudrāya paśupataye karṇā yāmā avaliptā raudrā nabhorūpāḥ pārjanyāḥ //
analyzed: śuddha vālaḥ sarva śuddha vālaḥ maṇivālaḥ te āśvināḥ śyetaḥ śyeta akṣaḥ ruṇaḥ te rudrāya paśupataye karṇāḥ yāmāḥ avaliptāḥ raudrāḥ nabhaḥ rūpāḥ pārjanyāḥ
translated: The pure-tailed, the all-pure-tailed, and the jewel-tailed are for the two Asvins. The white, the white-eyed, and the red are for Rudra, the lord of cattle. The pierced are for the Yamas. The Rudra ones have the form of the sky.

original: pṛśnis tiraścīnapṛśnir ūrdhvapṛśnis te mārutāḥ phalgūr lohitorṇī palakṣī tāḥ sārasvatyaḥ plīhākarṇaḥ śuṇṭhākarṇo 'ddhyālohakarṇas te tvāṣṭrāḥ kṛṣṇagrīvaḥ śitikakṣo 'ñjisakthas ta aindrāgnāḥ kṛṣṇāñjir alpāñjir mahāñjis ta uṣasyāḥ //
analyzed: pṛśniḥ tiraścīna pṛśniḥ ūrdhva pṛśniḥ te mārutāḥ phalgūḥ lohitorṇī palakṣī tāḥ sārasvatyaḥ plīhākarṇaḥ śuṇṭhākarṇaḥ te tvāṣṭrāḥ kṛṣṇa grīvaḥ śiti kakṣaḥ ñji sakthaḥ te aindrāgnāḥ kṛṣṇa añjiḥ alpa añjiḥ mahā añjiḥ te uṣasyāḥ
translated: The speckled, the cross-speckled, and the upward-speckled are for the Maruts. The reddish, the red-woolen, and the spotted are for Sarasvati. The spleen-eared, the swollen-eared, and the half-iron-eared are for Tvashtar. The black-necked, the white-flanked, and the smooth-legged are for Indra and Agni. The black-backed, the little-backed, and the big-backed are for Ushas.

original: śilpā vaiśvadevyo rohiṇyas tryavayo vāce 'vijñātā adityai sarūpā dhātre vatsataryo devānāṃ patnībhyaḥ //
analyzed: śilpāḥ vaiśvadevyaḥ rohiṇyaḥ tri avayaḥ vāce vijñātāḥ adityai sarūpāḥ dhātre vatsataryaḥ devānām patnībhyaḥ
translated: The speckled are for the All-gods. The red three-year-old ones are for Vayu. The unknown ones are for Aditi. The similar ones are for the nurse. The calf-tailed ones are for the wives of the gods.

original: kṛṣṇagrīvā āgneyāḥ śitibhravo vasūnām rohitā rudrāṇām śvetā avarokiṇa ādityānāṃ nabhorūpāḥ pārjanyāḥ //
analyzed: kṛṣṇa grīvāḥ āgneyāḥ śitibhravaḥ vasūnām rohitāḥ rudrāṇām śvetāḥ avarokiṇaḥ ādityānām nabhaḥ rūpāḥ pārjanyāḥ
translated: The black-necked ones are for Agni. The white-browed ones are for the Vasus. The red ones are for the Rudras. The white ones with black backs are for the Adityas. The sky-colored ones are for Parjanya.

original: unnata ṛṣabho vāmanas ta aindravaiṣṇavā unnataḥ śitibāhuḥ śitipṛṣṭhas ta aindrābārhaspatyāḥ śukarūpā vājināḥ kalmāṣā āgnimārutāḥ śyāmāḥ pauṣnāḥ //
analyzed: unnataḥ ṛṣabhaḥ vāmanaḥ te aindra vaiṣṇavāḥ unnataḥ śiti bāhuḥ śiti pṛṣṭhaḥ te aindrābārhaspatyāḥ śuka rūpāḥ vājināḥ kalmāṣāḥ āgnimārutāḥ śyāmāḥ pauṣnāḥ
translated: The tall, the bull, and the dwarf, these belong to Indra and Vishnu. The tall, the white-armed, and the white-backed, these belong to Indra and Brihaspati. The parrots, the horses, the dappled, these belong to Agni and the Maruts. The dark ones, these belong to Pushan.

original: etā aindrāgnā dvirūpā agnīṣomīyā vāmanā anaḍvāha āgnāvaiṣṇavā vaśā maitrāvaruṇyo 'nyataenyo maitryaḥ //🔽kṛṣṇagrīvā āgneyā babhravaḥ saumyāḥ śvetā vāyavyā avijñātā adityai sarūpā dhātre vatsataryo devānāṃ patnībhyaḥ //
analyzed: etāḥ aindrāgnāḥ dvi rūpāḥ agnīṣomīyāḥ vāmanāḥ anaḍvāhaḥ āgnāvaiṣṇavāḥ vaśāḥ maitrāvaruṇyaḥ nyataenyaḥ maitryaḥ  kṛṣṇa grīvāḥ āgneyāḥ babhravaḥ saumyāḥ śvetāḥ vāyavyāḥ avijñātāḥ adityai sarūpāḥ dhātre vatsataryaḥ devānām patnībhyaḥ
translated: These belong to Indra and Agni. The two-colored ones, these belong to Agni and Soma. The dwarfs, these belong to the bull. The heifers, these belong to Agni and Vishnu. The cows of different colors, these belong to Mitra and Varuna. The cows of one color, these belong to Mitra.🔽The black-necked ones, these belong to Agni. The brown ones, these belong to Soma. The white ones, these belong to Vayu. The unknown ones, these belong to Aditi. The ones of the same color, these belong to Dhatri. The calves, these belong to the wives of the gods.

original: kṛṣṇā bhaumā dhūmrā āntarikṣā bṛhanto divyāḥ śabalā vaidyutāḥ sidhmās tārakāḥ //
analyzed: kṛṣṇāḥ bhaumāḥ dhūmrāḥ āntarikṣāḥ bṛhantaḥ divyāḥ śabalāḥ vaidyutāḥ sidhmāḥ tārakāḥ
translated: The dark ones, these belong to the earth. The smoky ones, these belong to the atmosphere. The large ones, these belong to the sky. The variegated ones, these belong to the lightning. The decaying ones, these belong to the stars.

original: dhūmrān vasantāyā labhate śvetān grīṣmāya kṛṣṇān varṣābhyo 'ruṇāñ charade pṛṣato hemantāya piśaṅgāñ chiśirāya //
analyzed: dhūmrān vasantāyāḥ labhate śvetān grīṣmāya kṛṣṇān varṣābhyaḥ ruṇām śarade pṛṣataḥ hemantāya piśaṅgām śiśirāya
translated: He obtains the smoky ones for spring, the white ones for summer, the black ones for the rainy season, the red ones for autumn, the spotted ones for winter, and the tawny ones for the cold season.

original: tryavayo gāyatryai pañcāvayas triṣṭubhe dityavāho jagatyai trivatsā anuṣṭubhe turyavāha uṣṇihe //
analyzed: tryavayaḥ gāyatryai pañcāvayaḥ triṣṭubhe dityavāhaḥ jagatyai tri vatsāḥ anuṣṭubhe turyavāhaḥ uṣṇihe
translated: The three-year-old one for the Gayatri, the five-year-old one for the Tristubh, the one with the sun's color for the Jagati, the one with three calves for the Anustubh, and the one with four years' growth for the Ushnih.

original: paṣthavāho virāja ukṣaṇo bṛhatyā ṛṣabhāḥ kakubhe 'naḍvāhaḥ paṅktyai dhenavo 'ticchandase //
analyzed: paṣthavāhaḥ virājaḥ ukṣaṇaḥ bṛhatyāḥ ṛṣabhāḥ kakubhe naḍvāhaḥ paṅktyai dhenavaḥ ticchandase
translated: The oxen with the Virâg, the bulls with the Brihatî, the draught-oxen with the Kakup, the milch cows with the Paṅkti.

original: kṛṣṇagrīvā āgneyā babhravaḥ saumyā upadhvastāḥ sāvitrā vatsataryaḥ sārasvatyaḥ śyāmāḥ pauṣṇāḥ pṛśnayo mārutā bahurūpā vaiśvadevā vaśā dyāvāpṛthivīyāḥ //
analyzed: kṛṣṇa grīvāḥ āgneyāḥ babhravaḥ saumyāḥ upadhvastāḥ sāvitrāḥ vatsataryaḥ sārasvatyaḥ śyāmāḥ pauṣṇāḥ pṛśnayaḥ mārutāḥ bahu rūpāḥ vaiśvadevāḥ vaśāḥ dyāvāpṛthivīyāḥ
translated: Those with black necks are for Agni, the tawny ones for Soma, the weaned ones for Savitri, the calves for Sarasvatî, the dark ones for Pûshan, the parti-coloured ones for the Maruts, the many-coloured ones for the All-gods, the barren cows for Heaven and Earth.

original: uktāḥ saṃcarā etā aindrāgnāḥ kṛṣṇāḥ vāruṇāḥ pṛśnayo mārutāḥ kāyās tūparāḥ //
analyzed: uktāḥ saṃcarāḥ etāḥ aindrāgnāḥ kṛṣṇāḥ vāruṇāḥ pṛśnayaḥ mārutāḥ kāyāḥ tūparāḥ
translated: Those which are mentioned as changing are for Indra and Agni. The black ones are for Varuna, the parti-coloured ones for the Maruts, the hornless ones for the Kâyas.

original: agnaye 'nīkavate prathamajān ā labhate marudbhyaḥ sāṃtapanebhyaḥ savātyān marudbhyo gṛhamedhibhyo baṣkihān marudbhyaḥ krīḍibhyaḥ samsṛṣṭān marudbhyaḥ svatavadbhyo 'nusṛṣṭān //
analyzed: agnaye nīkavate prathama jān ā labhate marudbhyaḥ sāṃtapanebhyaḥ savātyān marudbhyaḥ gṛhamedhibhyaḥ baṣkihān marudbhyaḥ krīḍibhyaḥ samsṛṣṭān marudbhyaḥ svatavadbhyaḥ nusṛṣṭān
translated: To Agni Anikavant he seizes the first-born; to the Maruts Sântapanas those with a white back; to the Maruts Grhamedhas the Bashkiras; to the Maruts Kridins those which are mixed; to the Maruts Svatavas those which are mixed in succession.

original: uktāḥ saṃcarā etā aindrāgnāḥ prāśṛṅgā māhendrā bahurūpā vaiśvakarmaṇāḥ //
analyzed: uktāḥ saṃcarāḥ etāḥ aindrāgnāḥ prāśṛṅgāḥ māhendrāḥ bahu rūpāḥ vaiśvakarmaṇāḥ
translated: Those which are mentioned as changing are for Indra and Agni. Those with horns turned forward are for Mahendra, the many-coloured ones for Visvakarman.

original: dhūmrā babhrunīkāśāḥ pitṝṇām somavatāṃ babhravo babhrunīkāśāḥ pitṝṇāṃ barhiṣadāṃ kṛṣṇā babhrunīkāśāḥ pitṝṇām agniṣvāttānāṃ kṛṣṇāḥ pṛṣantas traiyambakāḥ //
analyzed: dhūmrāḥ babhru nīkāśāḥ pitṝṇām somavatām babhravaḥ babhru nīkāśāḥ pitṝṇām barhiṣadām kṛṣṇāḥ babhru nīkāśāḥ pitṝṇām agniṣvāttānām kṛṣṇāḥ pṛṣantaḥ traiyambakāḥ
translated: The smoke-coloured, tawny-coloured, belong to the Fathers who have Soma; the tawny, tawny-coloured, belong to the Fathers who sit on the sacrificial grass; the black, tawny-coloured, belong to the Fathers who have Agni; the black, spotted, belong to Tryambaka.

original: uktāḥ saṃcarā etā śunāsīrīyāḥ śvetā vāyavyāḥ śvetāḥ sauryāḥ //
analyzed: uktāḥ saṃcarāḥ śvetāḥ vāyavyāḥ śvetāḥ sauryāḥ
translated: The wandering (animals) have been mentioned. These are the Suna and Sirîya (victims). The white (animals) belong to Vâyu; the white (animals) belong to Sûrya.

original: vasantāya kapiñjalān ā labhate grīṣmāya kalaviṅkān varṣābhyas tittirīñ charade vartikā hemantāya kakarāñ chiśirāya vikakarān //
analyzed: vasantāya kapiñjalān ā labhate grīṣmāya kalaviṅkān varṣābhyaḥ tittirīm śarade vartikāḥ hemantāya kakarām śiśirāya vikakarān
translated: For spring he seizes the partridges; for summer the larks; for the rainy season the quails; for autumn the sparrows; for winter the kakaras; for the cool season the vikakarâs.

original: samudrāya śiśumārān a labhate parjanyāya maṇḍūkān adbhyo matsyān mitrāya kulīpayān varuṇāya nākrān //
analyzed: samudrāya śiśumārān a labhate parjanyāya maṇḍūkān adbhyaḥ matsyān mitrāya kulīpayān varuṇāya nākrān
translated: For the ocean he seizes the porpoises; for Parjanya the frogs; for the waters the fishes; for Mitra the kulipas; for Varuna the crocodiles.

original: somāya hamsān ā labhate vāyave balākā indrāgnibhyāṃ kruñcān mitrāya madgūn varuṇāya cakravākān //
analyzed: somāya hamsān ā labhate vāyave balākāḥ indra agnibhyām kruñcān mitrāya madgūn varuṇāya cakravākān
translated: For Soma he seizes the geese; for Vâyu the cranes; for Indra and Agni the Krunchas; for Mitra the Madgus; for Varuna the Chakravakas.

original: agnaye kuṭarūn ā labhate vanaspatibhya ulūkān agnīṣomābhyāṃ cāṣān aśvibhyāṃ mayūrān mitrāvaruṇābhyāṃ kapotān //
analyzed: agnaye kuṭarūn ā labhate vanaspatibhyaḥ ulūkān agnīṣomābhyām cāṣān aśvibhyām mayūrān mitrāvaruṇābhyām kapotān
translated: For Agni he seizes the Kûtarus; for the trees the owls; for Agni and Soma the Kâsas; for the two Asvins the peacocks; for Mitra and Varuna the pigeons.

original: somāya labān ā labhate tvaṣṭre kaulīkān goṣādīr devānāṃ patnībhyaḥ kulīkā devajāmibhyo 'gnaye gṛhapataye pāruṣṇān //🔽ahne pārāvatān ā labhate rātryai sīcāpūr ahorātrayoḥ saṃdhibhyo jatūr māsebhyo dātyauhānt saṃvatsarāya mahataḥ suparṇān //🔽bhūmyā ākhūn ā labhate 'ntarikṣāya pāṅktrān dive kaśān digbhyo nakulān babhrukān avāntaradiśābhyaḥ //🔽vasubhya ṛśyān ā labhate rudrebhyaḥ rurūn ādityebhyo nyaṅkūn viśvebhyo devebhyaḥ pṛṣatānt sādhyebhyaḥ kuluṅgān //
analyzed: somāya labān ā labhate tvaṣṭre kaulīkān goṣādīḥ devānām patnībhyaḥ kulīkāḥ deva jāmibhyaḥ gnaye gṛhapataye pāruṣṇān  ahne pārāvatān ā labhate rātryai sīcāpūḥ ahar rātrayoḥ saṃdhibhyaḥ jatūḥ māsebhyaḥ dātyauhān saṃvatsarāya mahataḥ suparṇān  bhūmyai ākhūn ā labhate ntarikṣāya pāṅktrān dive kaśān digbhyaḥ nakulān babhrukān avāntaradiśābhyaḥ  vasubhyaḥ ṛśyān ā labhate rudrebhyaḥ rurūn ādityebhyaḥ nyaṅkūn  viśvebhyaḥ devebhyaḥ pṛṣatān sādhyebhyaḥ kuluṅgān
translated: To Soma he offers the Laba; to Tvashtar the Kûlika; to the wives of the gods the Gosâdî; to the dames of the gods the Kûlikâ; to Agni, the lord of the house, the Pârushâ.🔽To the day he offers the Pârâvatas; to the night the Sîkâpûs; to the conjunctions of the day and night the Jatûs; to the months the Dâtyaus; to the year the great Suparnas.🔽To the earth he offers the moles; to the atmosphere the Paṅktras; to the sky the Kshânas; to the quarters the Nakulas and Babhrûkas; to the intermediate quarters.🔽To the Vasus he offers the Rishyas; to the Rudras the Rurus; to the Âdityas the Nyankus; to the Visve devâh the Prishtas; to the Sâdhyas the Kulungkâs.

original: īśānāya parasvata ā labhate mitrāya gaurān varuṇāya mahiṣān bṛhaspataye gavayāms tvaṣṭra uṣṭrān //🔽prajāpataye puruṣān hastina ā labhate vāce pluṣīmś cakṣuṣe maśakāñ chrotrāya bhṛṅgāḥ //
analyzed: īśānāya parasvate ā labhate mitrāya gaurān varuṇāya mahiṣān bṛhaspataye gavayāms tvaṣṭre uṣṭrān 🔽prajāpataye puruṣān hastinaḥ ā labhate vāce pluṣīm cakṣuṣe maśakām śrotrāya bhṛṅgāḥ
translated: To Soma he offers the Laba; to Tvashtar the Kûlika; to the wives of the gods the Gosâdî; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods; to the Kûlika the wives of the gods

original: prajāpataye ca vāyave ca gomṛgo varuṇāyāraṇyo meṣo yamāya kṛṣṇo manuṣyarājāya markaṭaḥ śārdūlāya rohid ṛṣabhāya gavayī kṣipraśyenāya vartikā nīlaṃgoḥ kṛmiḥ samudrāya śiśumāro himavate hastī //🔽mayuḥ prājāpatya ulo halikṣṇo vṛṣadamśas te dhātre diśāṃ kaṅko dhuṅkṣāgneyī kalaviṅko lohitāhiḥ puṣkarasādas te tvāṣṭrā vāce kruñcaḥ //
analyzed: prajāpataye ca vāyave ca gomṛgaḥ varuṇāya āraṇyaḥ meṣaḥ yamāya kṛṣṇaḥ manuṣya rājāya markaṭaḥ śārdūlāya rohit ṛṣabhāya gavayī kṣipraśyenāya vartikā nīlaṃgoḥ kṛmiḥ samudrāya śiśumāraḥ himavate hastī  mayuḥ prājāpatyaḥ ulaḥ halikṣṇaḥ vṛṣadamśaḥ te dhātre diśām kaṅkaḥ dhuṅkṣā āgneyī kalaviṅkaḥ lohita ahiḥ puṣkara sādaḥ te tvāṣṭrāḥ vāce kruñcaḥ
translated: The Gayal to Prajapati and Vayu, the wild ram to Varuna, the black one to Yama, the monkey to the king of men, the leopard to the tiger, the Gavaya to the bull, the sparrow to the swift hawk, the worm to the blue ox, the porpoise to the ocean, the elephant to the Himalaya.🔽The porcupine to Prajapati, the owl to the ploughman, the hare to the gambler, the crane to the nurse of the quarters, the heron to Agni, the sparrow to the red snake, the lotus-eater to Tvashtar, the cuckoo to speech.

original: somāya kuluṅga āraṇyo 'jo nakulaḥ śakā te pauṣṇāḥ kroṣṭā māyor indrasya gauramṛgaḥ pidvo nyaṅkuḥ kakkaṭas te 'numatyai pratiśrutkāyai cakravākaḥ //
analyzed: somāya kuluṅgaḥ āraṇyaḥ jaḥ nakulaḥ śakā te pauṣṇāḥ kroṣṭā māyoḥ indrasya gauramṛgaḥ pidvaḥ nyaṅkuḥ kakkaṭaḥ te numatyai pratiśrutkāyai cakravākaḥ
translated: The partridge to Soma, the wild goat to the forest, the mongoose to the rat, these to Pushan, the jackal to Maya, the gayal to Indra, the pindvi, the nyanku, the kakkata to Anumati, the ruddy goose to the echo.

original: saurī balākā śārgaḥ sṛjayaḥ śayāṇḍakas te maitrāḥ sarasvatyai śāriḥ puruṣavāk śvāvid bhaumī śārdūlo vṛkaḥ pṛdākus te manyave sarasvate śukaḥ puruṣavāk //
analyzed: saurī balākā śārgaḥ sṛjayaḥ śayāṇḍakaḥ te maitrāḥ sarasvatyai śāriḥ puruṣa vāc śvāvidh bhaumī śārdūlaḥ vṛkaḥ pṛdākuḥ te manyave sarasvate śukaḥ puruṣa vāc
translated: The crane to Surya, the sharga, the srijaya, the shayanda to Sarasvat, the sari to Sarasvati, the human voice, the porcupine to the earth, the leopard, the wolf, the python to Manyu, the parrot to Sarasvat, the human voice.

original: suparṇaḥ pārjanya ātir vāhaso darvidā te vāyave bṛhaspataye vācas pataye paiṅgarājo 'laja āntarikṣaḥ plavo madgur matsyas te nadīpataye dyāvāpṛthivīyaḥ kūrmaḥ //
analyzed: suparṇaḥ pārjanyaḥ ātiḥ vāhasaḥ darvidā te vāyave bṛhaspataye vācaḥ pataye paiṅgarājaḥ lajaḥ āntarikṣaḥ plavaḥ madguḥ matsyaḥ te nadīpataye dyāvāpṛthivīyaḥ kūrmaḥ
translated: The Suparna (bird) belongs to Parjanya, the Ati (bird) to Vayu, the Darvi-dada (bird) to Brihaspati, the Vâhas (bird) to the Lord of Speech. The Pingalâja (bird) belongs to Indra, the Alaja (bird) to the atmosphere, the Plava (bird) to the rivers, the Madgu (bird) and the Matsya (fish) to the Lord of the Rivers. The tortoise belongs to Heaven and Earth.

original: puruṣamṛgaś candramaso godhā kālakā dārvāghāṭas te vanaspatīnāṃ kṛkavākuḥ sāvitro hamso vātasya nākro makaraḥ kulīpayas te 'kūpārasya hriyai śalpakaḥ //
analyzed: puruṣa mṛgaḥ candramasaḥ godhā kālakā dārvāghāṭaḥ te vanaspatīnām kṛkavākuḥ sāvitraḥ hamsaḥ vātasya na akraḥ makaraḥ kulīpayaḥ te kūpārasya hriyai śalpakaḥ
translated: The Purusha-mriga (animal) belongs to the Moon, the Godha (lizard) to Kala, the Darvâghâta (animal) to the trees. The Krikara (cricket) belongs to Savitri, the Hamsa (swan) to Vâta, the Nâkra (serpent) to Akûpâra, the Makara (crocodile) and the Kûlîpaya (animal) to Hri.

original: eṇy ahno maṇḍūko mūṣikā tittiris te sarpāṇāṃ lopāśa āśvinaḥ kṛṣṇo rātryā ṛkṣo jatūḥ suṣilīkā ta itarajanānāṃ jahakā vaiṣṇavī //
analyzed: eṇī ahnaḥ maṇḍūkaḥ mūṣikā tittiriḥ te sarpāṇām lopāśaḥ āśvinaḥ kṛṣṇaḥ rātryāḥ ṛkṣaḥ jatūḥ suṣilīkā te itarajanānām jahakā vaiṣṇavī  /
translated: The Ena (animal) belongs to the day, the Mandûka (frog) to the night, the Mûshîka (mouse) and the Tittiri (partridge) to the serpents. The Lôpâsha (bird) belongs to the two Asvins, the Krsna (bird) to the night, the Rkṣa (bear) and the Jatû (porcupine) to the other people. The Su-silîkâ (animal) belongs to the Visvedevas, the Jahâka (bird) to Vishnu.

original: anyavāpo 'rdhamāsānām ṛśyo mayūraḥ suparṇas te gandharvāṇām apām udro māsāṃ kaśyapo rohit kuṇḍṛṇācī golattikā te 'psarasāṃ mṛtyave 'sitaḥ //
analyzed: anyavāpaḥ ṛdha māsānām ṛśyaḥ mayūraḥ suparṇaḥ te gandharvāṇām apām udraḥ māsām kaśyapaḥ rohit kuṇḍṛṇācī golattikā te psarasām mṛtyave sitaḥ
translated: The Anyavâpa (bird) belongs to the half-months, the Rkya (bird) to the months, the Mayûra (peacock) and the Suparna (bird) to the Gandharvas. The Udra (bird) belongs to the waters, the Kâsyapa (bird) to the months, the Rohita (fish) and the Kûdrunâkî (fish) to the Apsarases. The Golla-ttikâ (fish) belongs to Death, the Asita (fish) to the Asuras.

original: varṣāhūr ṛtūnām ākhuḥ kaśo mānthālas te pitṝṇāṃ balāyājagaro vasūnāṃ kapiñjalaḥ kapota ulūkaḥ śaśas te nirṛtyai varuṇāyāraṇyo meṣaḥ //
analyzed: varṣāhūḥ ṛtūnām ākhuḥ kaśaḥ mānthālaḥ te pitṝṇām balāya ajagaraḥ vasūnām kapiñjalaḥ kapotaḥ ulūkaḥ śaśaḥ te nirṛtyai varuṇāya āraṇyaḥ meṣaḥ
translated: The rain-cloud is for the Seasons; the mouse, the porcupine, the sloth-bear are for the Fathers; the python is for the Vasus; the partridge, the pigeon, the owl, the hare are for Nirriti; the wild ram is for Varuna.

original: śvitra ādityānām uṣṭro ghṛṇīvān vārdhrīṇasas te matyā araṇyāya sṛmaro rurū raudraḥ kvayiḥ kuṭarur dātyauhas te vājināṃ kāmāya pikaḥ //
analyzed: śvitraḥ ādityānām uṣṭraḥ ghṛṇīvān vārdhrīṇasaḥ te matyai araṇyāya sṛmaraḥ ruruḥ raudraḥ kvayiḥ kuṭaruḥ dātyauhaḥ te vājinām kāmāya pikaḥ
translated: The white-backed (animal) is for the Âdityas; the camel, the Ghriṇîvân, the Vârdhrînas are for Mati; the porcupine is for the Wild (Vishvâmitra); the Ruru, the Rudra, the Kvi, the Kûta-ru, the Dâtyûha are for the Vâjin (Maruts); the cuckoo is for Kama.

original: khaṅgo vaiśvadevaḥ śvā kṛṣṇaḥ karṇo gardabhas tarakṣus te rakṣasām indrāya sūkaraḥ simho mārutāḥ kṛkalāsaḥ pippakā śakunis te śaravyāyai viśveṣāṃ devānāṃ pṛṣataḥ //
analyzed: khaṅgaḥ vaiśvadevaḥ śvā kṛṣṇaḥ karṇaḥ gardabhaḥ tarakṣuḥ te rakṣasām indrāya sūkaraḥ simhaḥ mārutāḥ kṛkalāsaḥ pippakā śakuniḥ te śaravyāyai viśveṣām devānām pṛṣataḥ
translated: The rhinoceros is for the Visve Devâh; the black dog, the one-hoofed animal, the ass, the hyena are for the Rakshas; the boar is for Indra; the lion is for the Maruts; the iguana, the Pippaka, the bird are for Sharavyâ; the spotted (animal) is for the Visve Devâh.

original: śādaṃ dadbhir avakāṃ dantamūlair mṛdaṃ barsvais tegān damṣṭrābhyām sarasvatyā agrajihvaṃ jihvāyā utsādam avakrandena tālu vājam hanubhyām apa āsyena vṛṣaṇam āṇḍābhyām ādityām śmaśrubhiḥ panthānaṃ bhrūbhyāṃ dyāvāpṛthivī vartobhyāṃ vidyutaṃ kanīnakābhyām śuklāya svāhā kṛṣṇāya svāhā pāryāṇi pakṣmāṇy avāryā ikṣavo 'vāryāṇi pakṣmāṇi pāryā ikṣavaḥ //
analyzed: śādam dadbhiḥ avakām danta mūlaiḥ mṛdam barsvaiḥ tegān damṣṭrābhyām sarasvatyāḥ agrajihvam jihvāyāḥ utsādam avakrandena tālu vājam hanubhyām apaḥ āsyena vṛṣaṇam āṇḍābhyām ādityām śmaśrubhiḥ panthānam bhrūbhyām dyāvāpṛthivī vartobhyām vidyutam kanīnakābhyām śuklāya svāhā kṛṣṇāya svāhā pāryāṇi pakṣmāṇi a vāryāḥ ikṣavaḥ vāryāṇi pakṣmāṇi pāryāḥ ikṣavaḥ  /
translated: The grass with his teeth, the Avakâ with the roots of his teeth, the earth with his gums, the Tegas with his fangs, the Sarasvatî with the tip of his tongue, the Utsa with his tongue, the Avakranda with his palate, the strength with his jaws, the waters with his mouth, the testicles with his testicles, the Âditya with his beard, the path with his eyebrows, Heaven and Earth with his eyes, the lightning with his pupils. To the white hail! To the black hail! The outer feathers are the outer reeds, the inner feathers are the inner reeds.

original: vātaṃ prāṇenāpānena nasike upayāmam adhareṇauṣṭhena sad uttareṇa prakāśenāntaram anūkāśena bāhvyaṃ niveṣyaṃ mūrdhnā stanayitnuṃ nirbādhenāśaniṃ mastiṣkeṇa vidyutaṃ kanīnakābhyāṃ karṇābhyām śrotram śrotrābhyāṃ karṇau tedanīm adharakaṇṭhenāpaḥ śuṣkakaṇṭhena cittaṃ manyābhir aditim śīrṣṇā nirṛtiṃ nirjarjalpena śīrṣṇā saṃkrośaiḥ prāṇān reṣmāṇam stupena //
analyzed: vātam prāṇena apānena nasike upayāmam adhareṇa oṣṭhena sat uttareṇa prakāśena antaram anūkāśena bāhvyam niveṣyam mūrdhnā stanayitnum nirbādhena aśanim mastiṣkeṇa vidyutam kanīnakābhyām karṇābhyām śrotram śrotrābhyām karṇau tedanīm adhara kaṇṭhena apaḥ śuṣka kaṇṭhena cittam manyābhiḥ aditim śīrṣṇā nirṛtim nirjarjalpena śīrṣṇā saṃkrośaiḥ prāṇān reṣmāṇam stupena anuprāṇa anuprāṇa anuprāṇa anuprāṇa anuprāṇa
translated: The wind with the breath, with the out-breath, the nostrils with the lower lip, the truth with the upper, the light with the inner, the outer light with the external, the rain with the head, the thunder with the neck, the lightning with the brain, the eyes with the pupils, the ears with the ears, the hearing with the ears, the ears with the hearing, the tongue with the lower throat, the waters with the dry throat, the mind with the neck-bones, Aditi with the head, Nirriti with the neck, the cries with the head, the vital airs with the neck, the sighing with the crest.

original: maśakān keśair indram svapasā vahena bṛhaspatim śakunisādena kūrmāñ chapair ākramanam sthūrābhyām ṛkṣalābhiḥ kapiñjalān javaṃ jaṅghābhyām adhvānaṃ bāhubhyāṃ jāmbīlenāraṇyam agnim atirugbhyāṃ pūṣaṇaṃ dorbhyām aśvināv amsābhyām rudram rorābhyām //
analyzed: maśakān keśaiḥ indram su apasā vahena bṛhaspatim śakuni sādena kūrmām chapaiḥ ākramanam sthūrābhyām ṛkṣalābhiḥ kapiñjalān javam jaṅghābhyām adhvānam bāhubhyām jāmbīlena āraṇyam agnim atirugbhyām pūṣaṇam dorbhyām aśvinau amsābhyām rudram rorābhyām

with the neck, the lightning with the brain, the eyes with the pupils, the ears with the ears, the hearing with the ears, the ears with the ears, the teeth with the lower jaw, the waters with the dry with the skin, Brihaspati with the belly, the birds with the buttocks, the frogs with the hoofs, the creeping things with the thighs, the antelopes with the legs, the path with the feet, the original: agneḥ pakṣatir vāyor nipakṣatir indrasya tṛtīyā somasya caturthy adityai pañcamīndrāṇyai ṣaṣṭhī marutām saptamī bṛhaspater aṣṭamy aryamṇo navamī dhātur daśamīndrasyaikādaśī varuṇasya dvādaśī yamasya trayodaśī //
analyzed: agneḥ pakṣatiḥ vāyoḥ nipakṣatiḥ indrasya tṛtīyā somasya caturthī adityai pañcamī indrāṇyai ṣaṣṭhī marutām saptamī bṛhaspateḥ aṣṭamī aryamṇaḥ navamī dhātuḥ daśamī indrasya ekādaśī varuṇasya dvādaśī yamasya trayodaśī
translated: The right wing is of Agni, the left of Vayu, the third of Indra, the fourth of Soma, the fifth of Aditi, the sixth of Indrani, the seventh of the Maruts, the eighth of Brihaspati, the ninth of Aryaman, the tenth of Dhatr, the eleventh of Indra, the twelfth of Varuna, the thirteenth of Yama.

original: indrāgnyoḥ pakṣatir sarasvatyai nipakṣatir mitrasya tṛtīyāpāṃ caturthī nirṛtyai pañcamy agnīṣomayoḥ ṣaṣṭhī sarpāṇām saptamī viṣṇor aṣṭamī pūṣṇo navamī tvaṣṭur daśamīndrasyaikādaśī varuṇasya dvādaśī yamyai trayodaśī dyāvāpṛthivyor dakṣiṇaṃ pārśvaṃ viśveṣāṃ devānām uttaram //
analyzed: indra agnyoḥ pakṣatiḥ sarasvatyai nipakṣatiḥ mitrasya tṛtīyā apām caturthī nirṛtyai pañcamī agnīṣomayoḥ ṣaṣṭhī sarpāṇām saptamī viṣṇoḥ aṣṭamī pūṣṇaḥ navamī tvaṣṭuḥ daśamī indrasya ekādaśī varuṇasya dvādaśī yamyai trayodaśī dyāvāpṛthivyoḥ dakṣiṇam pārśvam viśveṣām devānām uttaram
translated: The right wing is of Indra and Agni, the left of Sarasvati, the third of Mitra, the fourth of the waters, the fifth of Nirriti, the sixth of Agni and Soma, the seventh of the serpents, the eighth of Vishnu, the ninth of Pushan, the tenth of Tvashtar, the eleventh of Indra, the twelfth of Varuna, the thirteenth of Yama, the right side is of the All-gods, the left of the Visve devatas.

original: marutām skandhā viśveṣāṃ devānāṃ prathamā kīkasā rudrāṇāṃ dvitīyādityānāṃ tṛtīyā vāyoḥ puccham agnīṣomayor bhāsadau kruñcau śroṇibhyām indrābṛhaspatī ūrubhyāṃ mitrāvaruṇāv algābhyām ākramaṇam sthūrābhyāṃ balaṃ kuṣṭhābhyām //
analyzed: marutām skandhāḥ viśveṣām devānām prathamā kīkasā rudrāṇām dvitīyā ādityānām tṛtīyā vāyoḥ puccham agnīṣomayoḥ bhāsadau kruñcau śroṇibhyām indrābṛhaspatī ūrubhyām mitrāvaruṇau algābhyām ākramaṇam sthūrābhyām balam kuṣṭhābhyām
translated: The Maruts' ribs, the Visvedevas' first knee-bones, the Rudras' second, the Âdityas' third, Vâyu's tail, the two Cruñchu (bones) are the two thighs of Agni and Soma, Indra and Brihaspati the two upper thighs, Mitra and Varuna the two knee-bones, the two fore-feet the two lower legs, the two hoofs the two feet.

original: pūṣaṇaṃ vaniṣṭhunāndhāhīnt sthūlagudayā sarpān gudābhir vihruta āntrair apo vastinā vṛṣaṇam āṇḍābhyāṃ vājinam śepena prajām retasā cāṣān pittena pradarān pāyunā kūśmāñ chakapiṇḍaiḥ //
analyzed: pūṣaṇam vaniṣṭhunā andhāhīn sthūlagudayā sarpān gudābhiḥ vihrutaḥ āntraiḥ apaḥ vastinā vṛṣaṇam āṇḍābhyām vājinam śepena prajām retasā cāṣān pittena pradarān pāyunā kūśmām śakapiṇḍaiḥ
translated: Pûshan the anus, the blind snake the thick tail, the serpents the entrails, the water the bladder, the testicles the two testicles, the strong one the penis, offspring the seed, the sparrows the bile, the discharges the anus, the pumpkin the balls of flesh.

original: indrasya krīḍo 'dityai pājasyaṃ diśāṃ jatravo 'dityai bhasaj jīmūtān hṛdayaupaśenāntarikṣaṃ purītatā nabha udaryeṇa cakravākau matasnābhyāṃ divaṃ vṛkkābhyāṃ girīn plāśibhir upalān plīhnā valmīkān klomabhir glaubhir gulmān hirābhiḥ sravantīr hradān kukṣibhyām samudram udareṇa vaiśvānaraṃ bhasmanā //
analyzed: indrasya krīḍaḥ dityai pājasyam diśām jatravaḥ dityai bhasad jīmūtān hṛdayaupaśena antarikṣam purītatā nabhaḥ udaryeṇa cakravākau matasnābhyām divam vṛkkābhyām girīn plāśibhiḥ upalān plīhnā valmīkān klomabhiḥ glaubhiḥ gulmān hirābhiḥ sravantīḥ hradān kukṣibhyām samudram udareṇa vaiśvānaram bhasmanā sarva antarikṣam antarikṣam antarikṣam antarikṣam antarikṣam antarikṣam antarikṣam antarikṣam antarikṣam antarikṣam antarikṣam a
translated: The play of Indra, the splendour of Aditi, the shoulders of the quarters, the breast of Aditi, the clouds are the heart's attendants, the atmosphere is the belly, the sky is the upper part, the Chakravaka birds are the lungs, the heaven is the liver, the mountains are the kidneys, the stones are the spleen, the ant-hills are the intestines, the bushes are the entrails, the streams are the bladder, the lakes are the belly, the ocean is the stomach, the fire of the bowels is the ashes.

original: vidhṛtiṃ nābhyā dhṛtam rasenāpo yūṣṇā marīcīr vipruḍbhir nīhāram ūṣmaṇā śīnaṃ vasayā pruṣvā aśrubhir hrādunīr dūṣīkābhir asnā rakṣāmsi citrāṇy aṅgair nakṣatrāṇi rūpeṇa pṛthivīṃ tvacā jumbakāya svāhā //
analyzed: vidhṛtim nābhyā dhṛtam rasena apaḥ yūṣṇā marīcīḥ vipruḍbhiḥ nīhāram  / ūṣmaṇā śīnam vasayā pruṣvā aśrubhiḥ hrādunīḥ dūṣīkābhiḥ asnā rakṣāmsi citrāṇi aṅgaiḥ nakṣatrāṇi rūpeṇa pṛthivīm tvacā jumbakāya svāhā
translated: The navel is the support, the waters are held by the juice, the sun's rays by the entrails, the dew by the heat, the rain by the fat, the tears by the moisture, the streams by the bile, the various forms by the limbs, the stars by the eyes, the earth by the skin. To that God we offer oblations.

original: hiraṇyagarbhaḥ sam avartatāgre bhūtasya jātaḥ patir eka āsīt / sa dādhāra pṛthivīṃ dyām utemāṃ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema //
analyzed: hiraṇya garbhaḥ sam avartata agre bhūtasya jātaḥ patiḥ ekaḥ āsīt    sa dādhāra pṛthivīm dyām uta imām kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
translated: Hiranyagarbha, in the beginning of creation, was born, the one Lord of all existing things. He supports this earth and the sky. To that God we offer oblations.

original: yaḥ prāṇato nimiṣato mahitvaika id rājā jagato babhūva / ya īśe asya dvipadaś catuṣpadaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema //
analyzed: yaḥ prāṇataḥ nimiṣataḥ mahitvā ekaḥ id rājā jagataḥ babhūva    yaḥ īśe asya dvipadaḥ catuṣpadaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
translated: Whose is this world of quadrupeds and bipeds: to what God shall we offer with oblation?🔽Whose is this world in greatness, whose the ocean, whom they call the Friend of the snow-clad mountain,

original: yasyeme himavanto mahitvā yasya samudram rasayā sahāhuḥ / yasyemāḥ pradiśo yasya bāhū kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema //
analyzed: yasya ime himavantaḥ mahitvā yasya samudram rasayā saha āhuḥ    yasya imāḥ pradiśaḥ yasya bāhū kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
translated: Whose are these regions, whose these arms on earth: to what God shall we offer with oblation?🔽Whose is the gift of life, whose is the gift of power, whom all obey, whose are the Gods,

original: ya ātmadā baladā yasya viśva upāsate praśiṣaṃ yasya devāḥ / yasya chāyāmṛtaṃ yasya mṛtyuḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema //
analyzed: yaḥ ātma dāḥ bala dāḥ yasya viśve upāsate praśiṣam yasya devāḥ yasya chāyā amṛtam yasya mṛtyuḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
translated: Whose shadow is immortality, whose shadow is death: to what God shall we offer with oblation?🔽Hither from all sides let our holy thoughts come unto us, uninjured, unassailed, and strong,

original: ā no bhadrāḥ kratavo yantu viśvato 'dabdhāso aparītāsa udbhidaḥ / devā no yathā sadam id vṛdhe asann aprāyuvo rakṣitāro divedive //
analyzed: ā naḥ bhadrāḥ kratavaḥ yantu viśvatas dabdhāsaḥ aparītāsaḥ udbhidaḥ    devāḥ naḥ yathā sadam id vṛdhe asan aprāyuvaḥ rakṣitāraḥ dive dive
translated: That the Gods may be ever with us for our weal, our guardians day by day, not turning from us.

original: devānāṃ bhadrā sumatir ṛjūyatāṃ devānām rātir abhi no ni vartatām / devānām sakhyam upa sedimā vayaṃ devā na āyuḥ pra tirantu jīvase //
analyzed: devānām bhadrā sumatiḥ ṛjūyatām devānām rātiḥ abhi naḥ ni vartatām    devānām sakhyam upa sedimā vayam devāḥ naḥ āyuḥ pra tirantu jīvase
translated: May the Gods' gracious favour be extended to us, may the Gods' bounty be directed towards us. We have approached the Gods' companionship. May the Gods prolong our life that we may live.

original: tān pūrvayā nividā hūmahe vayaṃ bhagaṃ mitram aditiṃ dakṣam asridham / aryamaṇaṃ varuṇam somam aśvinā sarasvatī naḥ subhagā mayas karat //
analyzed: tān pūrvayā nividā hūmahe vayam bhagam mitram aditim dakṣam asridham aryamaṇam varuṇam somam aśvinā sarasvatī naḥ subhagā mayaḥ karat
translated: Aryaman, Varuna, Soma, the Asvins. May Sarasvatî make us prosperous.🔽May the wind blow for us the healing balm, that balm, may the mother earth, may the father heaven,

original: tan no vāto mayobhu vātu bheṣajaṃ tan mātā pṛthivī tat pitā dyauḥ / tad grāvāṇaḥ somasuto mayobhuvas tad aśvinā śṛṇutaṃ dhiṣṇyā yuvam //
analyzed: tat naḥ vātaḥ mayobhu vātu bheṣajam tat mātā pṛthivī tat pitā dyauḥ   tat grāvāṇaḥ soma sutaḥ mayobhuvaḥ tat aśvinā śṛṇutam dhiṣṇyā yuvam
translated: that balm may the pressing-stones, that balm the Asvins, O ye two, that balm may the healing stones.🔽We call on him, the Lord of all that standeth and of all that moveth, him who sends forth our thoughts, to give us aid.

original: tam īśānaṃ jagatas tasthuṣas patiṃ dhiyaṃjinvam avase hūmahe vayam / pūṣā no yathā vedasām asad vṛdhe rakṣitā pāyur adabdhaḥ svastaye //
analyzed: tam īśānam jagataḥ tasthuṣas patim dhiyaṃjinvam avase hūmahe vayam     pūṣā naḥ yathā vedasām asat vṛdhe rakṣitā pāyuḥ adabdhaḥ svastaye
