original: yamena dattaṃ trita enam āyunag indra eṇaṃ prathamo adhy atiṣṭhat / gandharvo asya raśanām agṛbhṇāt sūrād aśvaṃ vasavo nir ataṣṭa //
analyzed: yamena dattam tritaḥ enam āyunak indraḥ eṇam prathamaḥ adhi atiṣṭhat    gandharvaḥ asya raśanām agṛbhṇāt sūrāt aśvam vasavaḥ niḥ ataṣṭa
translated: Trita hath guided him whom Yama gave, and Indra first of all hath stood beside him. The Gandharva hath taken hold of his rein: from Sûrya the Vasus have produced the Steed.

original: asi yamo asy ādityo arvann asi trito guhyena vratena / asi somena samayā vipṛkta āhus te trīṇi divi bandhanāni //
analyzed: asi yamaḥ asi ādityaḥ arvan asi tritaḥ guhyena vratena   asi somena samayā vipṛktaḥ āhuḥ te trīṇi divi bandhanāni
translated: Thou art Yama, thou art Âditya, O Steed, thou art Trita by the secret ordinance. Thou art separated by the Soma from the bond. They say that three bonds of thine are in the sky.

original: trīṇi ta āhur divi bandhanāni trīṇy apsu trīṇy antaḥ samudre / uteva me varuṇaś chantsy arvan yatrā ta āhuḥ paramaṃ janitram //
analyzed: trīṇi te āhuḥ divi bandhanāni trīṇi apsu trīṇi antar samudre    uta iva me varuṇaḥ chantsi arvan yatrā te āhuḥ paramam janitram
translated: Three bonds of thine, they say, are in the sky, three in the waters, three within the ocean. Even as a bird, O Steed, art thou to me, O Varuna, where they say is thy highest birthplace.

original: imā te vājinn avamārjanānīmā śaphānām sanitur nidhānā / atrā te bhadrā raśanā apaśyam ṛtasya yā abhirakṣanti gopāḥ //
analyzed: imā te vājin avamārjanāni imā śaphānām sanituḥ nidhānā     atrā te bhadrāḥ raśanāḥ apaśyam ṛtasya yāḥ abhirakṣanti gopāḥ
translated: These, O steed, are thy lower fetters, these the fastenings of thy hoofs, the bonds of thy fetterer. Here have I seen thy fair reins, the guards of truth, the keepers.

original: ātmānaṃ te manasārād ajānām avo divā patayantaṃ pataṃgam / śiro apaśyaṃ pathibhiḥ sugebhir areṇubhir jehamānaṃ patatri //
analyzed: ātmānam te manasā ārāt ajānām avas divā patayantam pataṃgam    śiraḥ apaśyam pathibhiḥ su gebhiḥ areṇubhiḥ jehamānam patatri
translated: I have known thy body by my mind, O bird, flying in the air by day. I have seen thy head, moving, flying, by the easy paths, by the paths free from dust.

original: atrā te rūpam uttamam apaśyaṃ jigīṣamāṇam iṣa ā pade goḥ / yadā te marto anu bhogam ānaḍ ād id grasiṣṭha oṣadhīr ajīgaḥ //
analyzed: atrā te rūpam uttamam apaśyam jigīṣamāṇam iṣaḥ ā pade goḥ    yadā te martaḥ anu bhogam ānaṭ āt id grasiṣṭhaḥ oṣadhīḥ ajīgaḥ
translated: Here have I seen thy highest form, striving for food at the foot of the cow, when the mortal man hath brought thee to thy enjoyment, then, O most greedy one, thou hast eaten the plants.

original: anu tvā ratho anu maryo arvann anu gāvo 'nu bhagaḥ kanīnām / anu vrātāsas tava sakhyam īyur anu devā mamire vīryaṃ te //
analyzed: anu tvā rathaḥ anu maryaḥ arvan anu gāvaḥ nu bhagaḥ kanīnām     anu vrātāsaḥ tava sakhyam īyuḥ anu devāḥ mamire vīryam te
translated: After thee, O steed, the chariot, the young man, the cows, the portion of the maidens, the bands of men have gone to thy friendship. The gods have measured thy strength.

original: hiraṇyaśṛṅgo 'yo asya pādā manojavā avara indra āsīt / devā id asya haviradyam āyan yo arvantaṃ prathamo adhyatiṣṭhat //
analyzed: hiraṇya śṛṅgaḥ yaḥ asya pādā manaḥ javāḥ avaraḥ indraḥ āsīt    devāḥ id asya haviḥ adyam āyan yaḥ arvantam prathamaḥ adhyatiṣṭhat
translated: Golden-horned was he, his feet were iron, his speed was that of thought, Indra was below. The gods have come to his oblation, who first mounted the horse.

original: īrmāntāsaḥ silikamadhyamāsaḥ sam śūraṇāso divyāso atyāḥ / hamsā iva śreṇiśo yatante yad ākṣiṣur divyam ajmam aśvāḥ //
analyzed: īrmāntāsaḥ silikamadhyamāsaḥ sam śūraṇāsaḥ divyāsaḥ atyāḥ   hamsāḥ iva śreṇiśas yatante yat ākṣiṣuḥ divyam ajmam aśvāḥ
translated: With long tails, with bellies like the cauldrons of stone, the heavenly steeds, the racers, have come. They strive in order, like swans, when the horses have drawn the heavenly car.

original: tava śarīraṃ patayiṣṇv arvan tava cittaṃ vāta iva dhrajīmān / tava śṛṅgāṇi viṣṭhitā purutrāraṇyeṣu jarbhurāṇā caranti //
analyzed: tava śarīram patayiṣṇu arvan tava cittam vātaḥ iva dhrajīmān    tava śṛṅgāṇi viṣṭhitā purutrā araṇyeṣu jarbhurāṇā caranti
translated: Thy body, O courser, is eager to fly, thy mind, like the wind, is impetuous. Thy horns are spread abroad in many places: they move, shaking, in the forests.

original: upa prāgāc chasanaṃ vājy arvā devadrīcā manasā dīdhyānaḥ / ajaḥ puro nīyate nābhir asyānu paścāt kavayo yanti rebhāḥ //
analyzed: upa prāgāt śasanam vājī arvā devadrīcā manasā dīdhyānaḥ    ajaḥ puras nīyate nābhiḥ asya anu paścāt kavayaḥ yanti rebhāḥ
translated: The strong courser has come to the place of worship, reflecting with a mind directed by the gods. The goat is led in front, this is his navel: the sages and the singers follow behind.

original: upa prāgāt paramaṃ yat sadhastham arvām acchā pitaraṃ mātaraṃ ca / adyā devān juṣṭatamo hi gamyā athā śāste dāśuṣe vāryāṇi //
analyzed: upa prāgāt paramam yat sadhastham arvām acchā pitaram mātaram ca          hi gamyāḥ athā śāste dāśuṣe vāryāṇi
translated: He has come to the highest place of assembly, to the father and the mother, from afar. Today thou must go to the gods as the most acceptable guest: then he will teach the worshipper what boons to ask.

original: samiddho adya manuṣo duroṇe devo devān yajasi jātavedaḥ / ā ca vaha mitramahaś cikitvān tvaṃ dūtaḥ kavir asi pracetāḥ //
analyzed: samiddhaḥ adya manuṣaḥ duroṇe devaḥ devān yajasi jātavedaḥ    ā ca vaha mitra mahas cikitvān tvam dūtaḥ kaviḥ asi pracetāḥ
translated: Kindled today in the house of Manu, O man, thou, O all-knowing Jâtavedas, worshippest the gods. And bringing (them), be thou observant, knowing, the messenger, the wise, the thoughtful.

original: tanūnapāt patha ṛtasya yānān madhvā samañjant svadayā sujihva / manmāni dhībhir uta yajñam ṛndhan devatrā ca kṛṇuhy adhvaraṃ naḥ //
analyzed: tanūnapāt pathaḥ ṛtasya yānān madhvā samañjan svadaya sujihva     manmāni dhībhiḥ uta yajñam ṛndhan devatrā ca kṛṇuhi adhvaram naḥ
translated: Tanûnapât, with honey, with thy sweetness, anoint the paths of sacrifice, O fair-tongued one. With thoughts and hymns make ready our oblations, and bring our sacrifice to the Gods.

original: narāśamsasya mahimānam eṣām upa stoṣāma yajatasya yajñaiḥ / ye sukratavaḥ śucayo dhiyaṃdhāḥ svadanti devā ubhayāni havyā //
analyzed: narāśamsasya mahimānam eṣām upa stoṣāma yajatasya yajñaiḥ    ye su kratavaḥ śucayaḥ dhiyaṃdhāḥ svadanti devāḥ ubhayāni havyā
translated: We will praise with our sacrifices the greatness of these, of Narâṣansa, of the worshipper, Who are of good counsel, pure, and thoughtful, who relish both kinds of offerings, O ye Gods.

original: ājuhvāna īḍyo vandyaś cā yāhy agne vasubhiḥ sajoṣāḥ / tvaṃ devānām asi yahva hotā sa enān yakṣīṣito yajīyān //🔽prācīnaṃ barhiḥ pradiśā pṛthivyā vastor asyā vṛjyate agre ahnām / vy u prathate vitaraṃ varīyo devebhyo aditaye syonam //
analyzed: ājuhvānaḥ īḍyaḥ vandyaḥ ca ā yāhi agne vasubhiḥ sajoṣāḥ   tvam devānām asi yahva hotā saḥ enān yakṣi iṣitaḥ yajīyān  prācīnam barhiḥ pradiśā pṛthivyāḥ vastoḥ asyāḥ vṛjyate agre ahnām    vi u prathate vitaram varīyaḥ devebhyaḥ aditaye syonam
translated: To be invoked, to be praised, to be worshipped, go thou, O Agni, with the Vasus in harmony. Thou art the young Hotar of the Gods: do thou, urged, most wise, worship them.🔽The ancient grass is strewn along the region of the earth, the first of all the days of the year. It spreadeth out, wide, wide, in ample room, delightful to the Gods and to Aditi.

original: vyacasvatīr urviyā vi śrayantāṃ patibhyo na janayaḥ śumbhamānāḥ / devīr dvāro bṛhatīr viśvaminvā devebhyo bhavata suprāyaṇāḥ //
analyzed: vyacasvatīḥ urviyā vi śrayantām patibhyaḥ na janayaḥ śumbhamānāḥ    devīḥ dvāraḥ bṛhatīḥ viśvaminvāḥ devebhyaḥ bhavata su prāyaṇāḥ
translated: Let the wide doors, like women decking themselves for their lords, be opened wide. Ye Goddesses, ye mighty doors, all-impelling, be easy of access to the Gods.

original: ā suṣvayantī yajate upāke uṣāsānaktā sadatāṃ ni yonau / divye yoṣaṇe bṛhatī surukme adhi śriyam śukrapiśaṃ dadhāne //
analyzed: ā yajate upāke uṣāsānaktā sadatām ni yonau
translated: The two Dawns, one to be invoked, the other to be worshipped, sit in their place, in their own home, to sacrifice. The two heavenly Maidens, lofty, with beautiful rims, bestowing upon us glory, bright and pure.

original: daivyā hotārā prathamā suvācā mimānā yajñaṃ manuṣo yajadhyai / pracodayantā vidatheṣu kārū prācīnaṃ jyotiḥ pradiśā diśantā //
analyzed: daivyā hotārā prathamā su vācā mimānā yajñam manuṣaḥ yajadhyai      pracodayantā vidatheṣu kārū prācīnam jyotiḥ pradiśā diśantā
translated: The two divine Hotars, first in good speech, allotting the sacrifice for man to worship, the two inspirers of devotion in assemblies, pointing out the light that is in the east, in the regions.

original: ā no yajñaṃ bhāratī tūyam etv iḍā manuṣvad iha cetayantī / tisro devīr barhir edam syonam sarasvatī svapasaḥ sadantu //
analyzed: ā naḥ yajñam bhāratī tūyam etu iḍā manuṣvat iha cetayantī    tisraḥ devīḥ barhiḥ ā idam syonam sarasvatī su apasaḥ sadantu
translated: May Bharati come quickly to our sacrifice, may Ida, mindful as among men, sit here. May the three Goddesses, Sarasvatî, and the two Asvins, sit on this pleasant sacred grass.

original: ya ime dyāvāpṛthivī janitrī rūpair apimśad bhuvanāni viśvā / tam adya hotar iṣito yajīyān devaṃ tvaṣṭāram iha yakṣi vidvān //
analyzed: yaḥ ime dyāvāpṛthivī janitrī rūpaiḥ apimśat bhuvanāni viśvā    tam adya hotar iṣitaḥ yajīyān devam tvaṣṭāram iha yakṣi vidvān
translated: He who hath measured out with forms these two, heaven and earth, the mothers, and all the worlds, him, O Hotar, this day, urged on, most worthy of worship, know thou, O wise one, as the god Tvashtar.

original: upāva sṛja tmanyā samañjan devānāṃ pātha ṛtuthā havīmṣi / vanaspatiḥ śamitā devo agniḥ svadantu havyaṃ madhunā ghṛtena //
analyzed: upa ava sṛja tmanyā samañjan devānām pāthaḥ ṛtuthā havīmṣi    vanaspatiḥ śamitā devaḥ agniḥ svadantu havyam madhunā ghṛtena
translated: Pouring thyself forth, uniting thyself, offer to the Gods the oblations in due season. The tree, the priest, the god Agni, let them relish the offering with honey and ghee.

original: sadyo jāto vy amimīta yajñam agnir devānām abhavat purogāḥ / asya hotuḥ pradiśy ṛtasya vāci svāhākṛtam havir adantu devāḥ //
analyzed: sadyas jātaḥ vi amimīta yajñam agniḥ devānām abhavat purogāḥ    asya hotuḥ pradiśi ṛtasya vāci svāhākṛtam haviḥ adantu devāḥ
translated: As soon as born he meted out the sacrifice: Agni became the leader of the Gods. In the direction of this our Hotar's holy word let the Gods cat the oblation offered with Svâhâ.

original: ketuṃ kṛṇvann aketave peśo maryā apeśase / sam uṣadbhir ajāyathāḥ //
analyzed: ketum kṛṇvan a ketave peśaḥ maryāḥ a peśase     sam uṣadbhiḥ ajāyathāḥ
translated: Making a banner for the bannerless, a form for those who have no form, thou art born with the dawns.

original: jīmūtasyeva bhavati pratīkaṃ yad varmī yāti samadām upasthe / anāviddhayā tanvā jaya tvam sa tvā varmaṇo mahimā pipartu //
analyzed: jīmūtasya iva bhavati pratīkam yat varmī yāti samadām upasthe   an āviddhayā tanvā jaya tvam sa tvā varmaṇaḥ mahimā pipartu
translated: As when the cloud assumes its aspect, when the mailed warrior advances to the conflict, be thou victorious with an unpierced body. Let the might of thy mail preserve thee.

original: dhanvanā gā dhanvanājiṃ jayema dhanvanā tīvrāḥ samado jayema / dhanuḥ śatror apakāmaṃ kṛṇoti dhanvanā sarvāḥ pradiśo jayema //🔽vakṣyantīved ā ganīganti karṇaṃ priyam sakhāyaṃ pariṣasvajānā / yoṣeva śiṅkte vitatādhi dhanvan jyā iyam samane pārayantī //
analyzed: dhanvanā gāḥ dhanvanā ājim jayema dhanvanā tīvrāḥ samadaḥ jayema  / dhanuḥ śatroḥ apakāmam kṛṇoti dhanvanā sarvāḥ pradiśaḥ jayema  vakṣyantī iva id ā ganīganti karṇam priyam sakhāyam pariṣasvajānā    yoṣā iva śiṅkte vitatā adhi dhanvan jyā iyam samane pārayantī
translated: With the bow we will win kine, with the bow the race-course, with the bow the strong exhilarating drinks. The bow makes the foe's will inoperative. With the bow we will win all the regions.🔽As if they would embrace his ear, the two quivers cling to his dear friend. The bow-string, stretched upon the bow, twangs like a woman. This string will carry us through the conflict.

original: te ācarantī samaneva yoṣā māteva putraṃ bibhṛtām upasthe / apa śatrūn vidhyatām saṃvidāne ārtnī ime viṣphurantī amitrān //
analyzed: te ācarantī samanā iva yoṣā mātā iva putram bibhṛtām upasthe    apa śatrūn vidhyatām saṃvidāne ārtnī ime viṣphurantī amitrān
translated: They move around like two women in the dance. Let them bear him in their lap like a mother her son. Let these two arrows, in unison, pierce the foes. Let these two bows, expanding, crush the enemies.

original: bahvīnāṃ pitā bahur asya putraś ciścā kṛṇoti samanāvagatya / iṣudhiḥ saṅkāḥ pṛtanāś ca sarvāḥ pṛṣṭhe ninaddho jayati prasūtaḥ //
analyzed: bahvīnām pitā bahuḥ asya putraḥ kṛṇoti samanā avagatya    iṣudhiḥ saṅkāḥ pṛtanāḥ ca sarvāḥ pṛṣṭhe ninaddhaḥ jayati prasūtaḥ
translated: The quiver, fastened on the back, conquers all the troops and armies, sent forth,🔽Standing in the chariot, the charioteer leads the horses to the place he wishes, the skillful charioteer.🔽The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.

original: rathe tiṣṭhan nayati vājinaḥ puro yatrayatra kāmayate suṣārathiḥ / abhīśūnāṃ mahimānaṃ panāyata manaḥ paścād anu yacchanti raśmayaḥ //
analyzed: rathe tiṣṭhan nayati vājinaḥ puras yatra yatra kāmayate suṣārathiḥ    abhīśūnām mahimānam panāyata manaḥ paścāt anu yacchanti raśmayaḥ
translated: The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.🔽The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.🔽The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.🔽The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.

original: tīvrān ghoṣān kṛṇvate vṛṣapāṇayo 'śvā rathebhiḥ saha vājayantaḥ / avakrāmantaḥ prapadair amitrān kṣiṇanti śatrūmr anapavyayantaḥ //
analyzed: tīvrān ghoṣān kṛṇvate vṛṣa pāṇayaḥ śvā rathebhiḥ saha vājayantaḥ     avakrāmantaḥ prapadaiḥ amitrān kṣiṇanti śatrūm an apavyayantaḥ
translated: The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.

original: rathavāhanam havir asya nāma yatrāyudhaṃ nihitam asya varma / tatrā ratham upa śagmam sadema viśvāhā vayam sumanasyamānāḥ //
analyzed: rathavāhanam haviḥ asya nāma yatra āyudham nihitam asya varma    tatra ratham upa śagmam sadema viśvāhā vayam sumanasyamānāḥ
translated: The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.🔽The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.🔽The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.🔽The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.🔽The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.🔽The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.🔽The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held by the charioteer.

original: svāduṣamsadaḥ pitaro vayodhāḥ kṛcchreśritaḥ śaktīvanto gabhīrāḥ / citrasenā iṣubalā amṛdhrāḥ satovīrā uravo vrātasāhāḥ //
analyzed: svāduṣamsadaḥ pitaraḥ vayaḥ dhāḥ kṛcchreśritaḥ śaktīvantaḥ gabhīrāḥ citra senāḥ iṣu balāḥ amṛdhrāḥ satovīrāḥ uravaḥ vrāta sāhāḥ
translated: The horses, neighing loudly, yoked with the chariots, go to the place they are led. The reins are held

original: brāhmaṇāsaḥ pitaraḥ somyāsaḥ śive no dyāvāpṛthivī anehasā / pūṣā naḥ pātu duritād ṛtāvṛdho rakṣā mākir no aghaśamsa īśata //
analyzed: brāhmaṇāsaḥ pitaraḥ somyāsaḥ śive naḥ dyāvāpṛthivī anehasā   pūṣā naḥ pātu duritāt ṛtāvṛdhaḥ rakṣā mākir naḥ agha śamsaḥ īśata
translated: The Fathers who are served with Soma, the Brahmans, may Heaven and Earth, auspicious, free from sin, protect us. May Pûshan, who strengthens truth, preserve us from misfortune. Let not the evil-wisher rule over us.

original: suparṇaṃ vaste mṛgo asyā danto gobhiḥ saṃnaddhā patati prasūtā / yatrā naraḥ saṃ ca vi ca dravanti tatrāsmabhyam iṣavaḥ śarma yamsan //
analyzed: suparṇam vaste mṛgaḥ asyāḥ dantaḥ gobhiḥ saṃnaddhā patati prasūtā    yatrā naraḥ sam ca vi ca dravanti tatra asmabhyam iṣavaḥ śarma yamsan
translated: She is clothed in the bird, the deer is her tooth. She flies forth, bound with the cows. Where men run together and run away, there let the shafts give us protection.

original: ṛjīte pari vṛṅdhi no 'śmā bhavatu nas tanūḥ / somo adhi bravītu no 'ditiḥ śarma yacchatu //
analyzed: ṛjīte pari vṛṅdhi naḥ śmā bhavatu naḥ tanūḥ   somaḥ adhi bravītu naḥ ditiḥ śarma yacchatu
translated: O thou of the dart, encompass us about. Let our body be as a rock. Let Soma speak unto us. Let Aditi give us protection.

original: ā jaṅghanti sānv eṣāṃ jaghanām upa jighnate / aśvājani pracetaso 'śvānt samatsu codaya //
analyzed: ā jaṅghanti sānū eṣām jaghanām upa jighnate     aśvājani pracetasaḥ śvān samatsu codaya
translated: They strike their shoulders, they strike their hips. O thou who art born of the horse's womb, thou who art wise, urge the horses to the combat.

original: ahir iva bhogaiḥ pary eti bāhuṃ jyāyā hetiṃ paribādhamānaḥ / hastaghno viśvā vayunāni vidvān pumān pumāmsaṃ pari pātu viśvataḥ //
analyzed: ahiḥ iva bhogaiḥ pari eti bāhum jyāyāḥ hetim paribādhamānaḥ    hastaghnaḥ viśvā vayunāni vidvān pumān pumāmsam pari pātu viśvatas
translated: Like a serpent with his coils he compasses the arm, warding off the arrow's shaft. The smiter of the hand, who knoweth all the ways, may the male being guard the male being on every side.

original: vanaspate vīḍvaṅgo hi bhūyā asmatsakhā prataraṇaḥ suvīraḥ / gobhiḥ saṃnaddho asi vīḍayasvāsthātā te jayatu jetvāni //
analyzed: vanaspate vīḍu aṅgaḥ hi bhūyāḥ asmad sakhā prataraṇaḥ su vīraḥ   gobhiḥ saṃnaddhaḥ asi vīḍayasva āsthātā te jayatu jetvāni
translated: O tree, be thou strong-limbed, a friend to us, a deliverer, with goodly heroes. Thou art bound with the cows. Strengthen thyself. Let him who dependeth on thee win all victories.

original: divaḥ pṛthivyāḥ pary oja udbhṛtaṃ vanaspatibhyaḥ pary ābhṛtam sahaḥ / apām ojmānaṃ pari gobhir āvṛtam indrasya vajram haviṣā rathaṃ yaja //
analyzed: divaḥ pṛthivyāḥ pari ojaḥ udbhṛtam vanaspatibhyaḥ pari ābhṛtam sahaḥ    apām ojmānam pari gobhiḥ āvṛtam indrasya vajram haviṣā ratham yaja
translated: The strength of waters, compassed round with milk, the car of Indra, the thunderbolt, I worship with oblation.🔽The thunderbolt of Indra, the van of the Maruts, the embryo of Mitra, the navel of Varuna,

original: indrasya vajro marutām anīkaṃ mitrasya garbho varuṇasya nābhiḥ / semāṃ no havyadātiṃ juṣāṇo deva ratha prati havyā gṛbhāya //
analyzed: indrasya vajraḥ marutām anīkam mitrasya garbhaḥ varuṇasya nābhiḥ    sa imām naḥ havya dātim juṣāṇaḥ deva ratha prati havyā gṛbhāya
translated: Accepting this our offering, O God-borne Car, receive our oblations, O thou who art borne by the Gods.🔽Bellow against the earth and against the sky. Let the world that standeth in many places obey thee.

original: upa śvāsaya pṛthivīm uta dyāṃ purutrā te manutāṃ viṣṭhitaṃ jagat / sa dundubhe sajūr indreṇa devair dūrād davīyo apa sedha śatrūn //
analyzed: upa śvāsaya pṛthivīm uta dyām purutrā te manutām viṣṭhitam jagat    sa dundubhe sajūs indreṇa devaiḥ dūrāt davīyaḥ apa sedha śatrūn
translated: Thou, O drum, being of one mind with Indra and the Gods, drive away the foes from far away.🔽Roar out strength, bestow strength and vigour on us, neighing loudly, driving away evils.

original: ā krandaya balam ojo na ā dhā ni ṣṭanihi duritā bādhamānaḥ / apa protha dundubhe ducchunā ita indrasya muṣṭir asi vīḍayasva //
analyzed: ā krandaya balam ojaḥ naḥ ā dhāḥ ni stanihi duritā bādhamānaḥ   apa protha dundubhe ducchunāḥ itas indrasya muṣṭiḥ asi vīḍayasva
translated: Roar away, O drum, misfortune from us. Thou art the fist of Indra: be thou strong.🔽Turn hither, O goat, these (cows) of ours. The bannered drum sounds forth.

original: āmūr aja pratyā vartayemāḥ ketumad dundubhir vāvadīti / sam aśvaparṇāś caranti no naro 'smākam indra rathino jayantu //
analyzed: ā amūḥ aja pratyā vartaya imāḥ ketumat dundubhiḥ vāvadīti   / sam aśva parṇāḥ caranti naḥ naraḥ smākam indra rathinaḥ jayantu
translated: Our men, winged with horses, move about. Let our car-warriors, O Indra, be victorious.

original: āgneyaḥ kṛṣṇagrīvaḥ sārasvatī meṣī babhruḥ saumyaḥ pauṣṇaḥ śyāmaḥ śitipṛṣṭho bārhaspatyaḥ śilpo vaiśvadeva aindro 'ruṇo mārutaḥ kalmāṣa aindrāgnaḥ samhito 'dhorāmaḥ sāvitro vāruṇaḥ kṛṣṇa ekaśitipāt petvaḥ //
analyzed: āgneyaḥ kṛṣṇa grīvaḥ sārasvatī meṣī babhruḥ saumyaḥ pauṣṇaḥ śyāmaḥ śiti pṛṣṭhaḥ bārhaspatyaḥ śilpaḥ vaiśvadevaḥ aindraḥ ruṇaḥ mārutaḥ kalmāṣaḥ aindrāgnaḥ samhitaḥ dhorāmaḥ sāvitraḥ vāruṇaḥ kṛṣṇaḥ eka śiti pād petvaḥ
translated: The black-necked one to Agni, the ewe to Sarasvatî, the brown one to Soma, the dark one with white back to Pûshan, the speckled one to Brihaspati, the goat to the All-gods, the red one to Indra, the piebald one to the Maruts, the speckled one to Indra and Agni, the one with a white back to Savitar, the black one to Varuna, the ram to Tvastr.

original: agnaye 'nīkavate rohitāñjir anaḍvān adhorāmau sāvitrau pauṣṇau rajatanābhī vaiśvadevau piśaṃgau tūparau mārutaḥ kalmāṣa āgneyaḥ kṛṣṇo 'jaḥ sārasvatī meṣī vāruṇaḥ petvaḥ //
analyzed: agnaye nīkavate rohita añjiḥ anaḍvān adhorāmau sāvitrau pauṣṇau rajata nābhī vaiśvadevau piśaṃgau tūparau mārutaḥ kalmāṣaḥ āgneyaḥ kṛṣṇaḥ jaḥ sārasvatī meṣī vāruṇaḥ petvaḥ
translated: To Agni, the leader, an ox with red mark on the forehead, two with white backs to Savitar, two to Pûshan with silver navels, two tawny rams to the All-gods, the piebald one to the Maruts, the black one to Agni, the ewe to Sarasvatî, the ram to Varuna.

original: agnaye gāyatrāya trivṛte rāthantarāyāṣṭākapāla indrāya traiṣṭubhāya pañcadaśāya barhatāyaikādaśakapālo viśvebhyo devebhyo jāgatebhyaḥ saptadaśebhyo vairūpebhyo dvādaśakapālo mitrāvaruṇābhyām ānuṣṭubhābhyām ekavimśābhyāṃ vairājābhyāṃ payasyā bṛhaspataye pāṅktāya triṇavāya śākvarāya caruḥ savitra auṣṇihāya trayastrimśāya raivatāya dvādaśakapālaḥ prājāpatyaś carur adityai viṣṇupatnyai carur agnaye vaiśvānarāya dvādaśakapālo 'numatyā aṣṭākapālaḥ //
analyzed: agnaye gāyatrāya trivṛte rāthantarāya aṣṭākapālaḥ indrāya traiṣṭubhāya pañcadaśāya barhatāya ekādaśa kapālaḥ viśvebhyaḥ devebhyaḥ jāgatebhyaḥ saptadaśebhyaḥ vairūpebhyaḥ dvādaśa kapālaḥ mitrāvaruṇābhyām ānuṣṭubhābhyām ekavimśābhyām vairājābhyām payasyā bṛhaspataye pāṅktāya triṇavāya śākvarāya caruḥ savitre auṣṇihāya trayastrimśāya raivatāya dvādaśa kapālaḥ prājāpatyaḥ caruḥ adityai viṣṇu patnyai caruḥ
translated: To Agni, of the Gayatri (hymn-metre), the Trivrit (stoma), the Rathantara (Saman), on eight potsherds; to Indra, of the Tristubh, the Pañcadaça (stoma), the Brihat (Saman), on eleven potsherds; to the All-gods, of the Jagati, the Saptadaça (stoma), the Vairûpa (Saman), on twelve potsherds; to Mitra and Varuna, of the Anustubh, the Ekavinça (stoma), the Vairaja (Saman), an oblation of curds; to Brihaspati, of the Pankti (metre), the Trinava (stoma), the Çakvara (Saman), an oblation of boiled rice; to Savitri, of the Usnih (metre), the Trayastrimsa (stoma), the Raivata (Saman), on twelve potsherds; an oblation to Pragâpati; an oblation to Aditi, the wife of Vishnu; to Agni Vaisvânara, on twelve potsherds; to Anumati, on eight potsherds.

original: deva savitaḥ pra suva yajñaṃ pra suva yajñapatiṃ bhagāya / divyo gandharvaḥ ketupūḥ ketaṃ naḥ punātu vācaspatir vājaṃ naḥ svadatu //
analyzed: deva savitar pra suva yajñam pra suva yajñapatim bhagāya     divyaḥ gandharvaḥ ketu pūḥ ketam naḥ punātu vācaspatiḥ vājam naḥ svadatu  /
translated: O God Savitar, impel the sacrifice, impel the lord of the sacrifice to prosperity. May the heavenly Gandharva, the purifier of thought, purify our thought. May the lord of speech sweeten our speech.

original: tat savitur vareṇyaṃ bhargo devasya dhīmahi / dhiyo yo naḥ pracodayat //
analyzed: tat savituḥ vareṇyam bhargaḥ devasya dhīmahi dhiyaḥ yaḥ naḥ pracodayat
translated: We meditate on that excellent glory of Savitar the God: may he stimulate our prayers.

original: viśvāni deva savitar duritāni parā suva / yad bhadraṃ tan na ā suva //
analyzed: viśvāni deva savitar duritāni parā suva   yat bhadram tat naḥ ā suva
translated: O God Savitar, send away all our misfortunes, and bring to us what is good.

original: vibhaktāram havāmahe vasoś citrasya rādhasaḥ / savitāraṃ nṛcakṣasam //
analyzed: vibhaktāram havāmahe vasoḥ citrasya rādhasaḥ    savitāram nṛ cakṣasam
translated: We invoke the Disposer of the wondrous gift of wealth, Savitar, the God who looks on men.

original: brahmaṇe brāhmaṇaṃ kṣatrāya rājanyaṃ marudbhyo vaiśyaṃ tapase śūdraṃ tamase taskaraṃ nārakāya vīrahaṇaṃ pāpmane klībam ākrayāyā ayogūṃ kāmāya pumścalūm atikruṣṭāya māgadham //
analyzed: brahmaṇe brāhmaṇam kṣatrāya rājanyam marudbhyaḥ vaiśyam tapase śūdram tamase taskaram nārakāya vīra haṇam pāpmane klībam ākrayāya ayogūm kāmāya pumścalūm atikruṣṭāya māgadham
translated: To Brahman the Brahmana, to Kshatra the Kshatriya, to the Maruts the Vaishya, to Tapas the Shudra, to Tama the thief, to Naraka the slayer of heroes, to Papman the eunuch, to Akraya the impotent, to Kama the adulteress, to Atikrushta the Magadha.

original: nṛttāya sūtaṃ gītāya śailūṣaṃ dharmāya sabhācaraṃ nariṣṭhāyai bhīmalaṃ narmāya rebham hasāya kārim ānandāya strīṣukhaṃ pramade kumārīputraṃ medhāyai rathakāraṃ dhairyāya takṣāṇam //
analyzed: nṛttāya sūtam gītāya śailūṣam dharmāya sabhācaram nariṣṭhāyai bhīmalam narmāya rebham hasāya kārim ānandāya strīṣukham pramade kumārīputram medhāyai rathakāram dhairyāya takṣāṇam
translated: To Nrtya the Suta, to Gita the Shailusha, to Dharma the Sabhachara, to Narisht the Bhimalam, to Nrma the Rebha, to Hasya the Kari, to Ananda the woman-lover, to Pramada the maiden's son, to Medha the Rathkar, to Dhairya the carpenter.

original: tapase kaulālaṃ māyāyai karmāram rūpāya maṇikāram śubhe vapam śaravyāyā iṣukāram hetyai dhanuṣkāraṃ karmaṇe jyākāraṃ diṣṭāya rajjusarjaṃ mṛtyave mṛgayum antakāya śvaninam //
analyzed: tapase kaulālam māyāyai karmāram rūpāya maṇikāram śubhe vapam śaravyāyai iṣukāram hetyai dhanuṣkāram karmaṇe jyākāram diṣṭāya  / rajju sarjam mṛtyave mṛgayum antakāya śvaninam
translated: To Tapas the potter, to Maya the blacksmith, to Rupa the jeweller, to Shubha the barber, to Sharavya the arrow-maker, to Heti the bow-maker, to Karma the string-maker, to Dhisht the rope-maker, to Mrityu the hunter, to Antaka the dog-keeper.

original: nadībhyaḥ pauñjiṣṭham ṛkṣīkābhyo naiṣādaṃ puruṣavyāghrāya durmadaṃ gandharvāpsarobhyo vrātyaṃ prayugbhya unmattam sarpadevajanebhyo 'pratipadamayebhyaḥ kitavam īryatāyā akitavaṃ piśācebhyo bidalakārīṃ yātudhānebhyaḥ kaṇṭakīkārīm //🔽saṃdhaye jāraṃ gehāyopapatim ārtyai parivittaṃ nirṛtyai parivividānam arāddhyā edidhiṣuḥpatiṃ niṣkṛtyai peśaskārīm saṃjñānāya smarakārīṃ prakāmodyāyopasadaṃ varṇāyānurudhaṃ balāyopadām //
analyzed: nadībhyaḥ pauñjiṣṭham ṛkṣīkābhyaḥ naiṣādam puruṣa vyāghrāya durmadam gandharva apsarobhyaḥ vrātyam prayugbhyaḥ unmattam sarpa deva janebhyaḥ pratipad a mayebhyaḥ kitavam akitavam piśācebhyaḥ bidalakārīm yātudhānebhyaḥ kaṇṭakīkārīm  saṃdhaye jāram gehāya upapatim ārtyai parivittam nirṛtyai parivividānam arāddhyai edidhiṣuḥ patim niṣkṛtyai peśaskārīm saṃjñānāya smarakārīm prakāmodyāya upasadam varṇāya anurudham balāya upadām
translated: From the rivers, the son of Pūjishtha; from the Rīkshikas, the son of Nishada; from the tiger among men, the son of Durmada; from the Gandharvas and Apsarases, the son of the Vrātya; from the Yugmas, the son of the Unmatta; from the serpent tribes and the people of the gods, the son of the Aprapad; from the Kitavas, the son of the Kitava; from the Pishachas, the son of the Vidalakari; from the Yātudhānas, the son of the Kantakārikā.🔽From the Sandhyas, the son of the Jar; from the house, the son of the Upapatti; from the Arati, the son of the Parivitta; from the Nirriti, the son of the Parivividāna; from the Arādhya, the son of the Edihisupatī; from the Niskṛti, the son of the Peshaskari; from the Samjñāna, the son of the Smarakari; from the Prakāmaudyāya, the son of the Upaśada; from the Varna, the son of the Anurudha; from the Bala, the son of the Upadā.

original: utsādebhyaḥ kubjaṃ pramude vāmanaṃ dvārbhyaḥ srāmam svapnāyāndham ardhamāya badhiraṃ pavitrāya bhiṣajaṃ prajñānāya nakṣatradarśam āśikṣāyai praśninam upaśikṣāyā abhipraśninaṃ maryādāyai praśnavivākam //
analyzed: utsādebhyaḥ kubjam pramude vāmanam dvārbhyaḥ srāmam svapnāya andham ardhamāya badhiram pavitrāya bhiṣajam prajñānāya nakṣatra darśam āśikṣāyai praśninam upaśikṣāyai abhipraśninam maryādāyai praśna vivākam
translated: From the Utsādas, the son of the Kubja; from the Pramuda, the son of the Vāmana; from the doors, the son of the Srama; from the sleep, the son of the Andha; from the half-month, the son of the Badhira; from the Pavitra, the son of the Bhishaja; from the Prajñāna, the son of the Nakṣatradarśa; from the Āśikṣā, the son of the Prashnin; from the Upaśikṣā, the son of the Abhiprashnin; from the Marīyāda, the son of the Prashnavivāka.

original: armebhyo hastipaṃ javāyāśvapaṃ puṣṭyai gopālaṃ vīryāyāvipālaṃ tejase 'japālam irāyai kīnāśaṃ kīlālāya surākāraṃ bhadrāya gṛhapam śreyase vittadham ādhyakṣyāyānukṣattāram //🔽bhāyai dārvāhāraṃ prabhāyā agnyedhaṃ bradhnasya viṣṭapāyābhiṣektāraṃ varṣiṣṭhāya nākāya pariveṣṭāraṃ devalokāya peśitāraṃ manuṣyalokāya prakaritāram sarvebhyo lokebhya upasektāram avaṛtyai badhāyopamanthitāraṃ medhāya vāsaḥpalpūlīṃ prakāmāya rajayitrīm //
analyzed: armebhyaḥ hastipam javāya aśvapam puṣṭyai gopālam vīryāya avipālam tejase japālam irāyai kīnāśam kīlālāya surā kāram bhadrāya gṛhapam śreyase vitta dham ādhyakṣyāya anukṣattāram  bhāyai dārva āhāram prabhāyai agnyedham bradhnasya viṣṭapāya abhiṣektāram varṣiṣṭhāya nākāya pariveṣṭāram deva lokāya peśitāram manuṣya lokāya prakaritāram sarvebhyaḥ lokebhyaḥ upasektāram avaṛtyai badhāya upamanthitāram medhāya vāsaḥ palpūlīm prakāmāya rajayitrīm
translated: For the arms, the elephant-keeper; for speed, the horse-keeper; for nourishment, the cow-keeper; for strength, the sheep-keeper; for splendour, the goat-keeper; for food, the swine-herd; for sweet drink, the brewer; for prosperity, the householder; for welfare, the treasurer; for supervision, the superintendent.🔽For fear, the wood-gatherer; for light, the fire-kindler; for the breadth of the atmosphere, the anointer; for the highest heaven, the encircler; for the world of the gods, the weaver; for the world of men, the distributor; for all the worlds, the sprinkler; for concealment, the beater; for wisdom, the cloth-maker; for desire, the dyer.

original: ṛtaye stenahṛdayaṃ vairahatyāya piśunaṃ viviktyai kṣattāram aupadraṣṭryāyānukṣattāraṃ bālāyānucaraṃ bhūmne pariṣkandaṃ priyāya priyavādinam ariṣṭyā aśvasādam svargāya lokāya bhāgadughaṃ varṣiṣṭhāya nākāya pariveṣṭāram //
analyzed: ṛtaye stena hṛdayam vaira hatyāya piśunam viviktyai kṣattāram aupadraṣṭryāya anukṣattāram bālāya anucaram bhūmne pariṣkandam priyāya priya vādinam ariṣṭyai aśvasādam svargāya lokāya bhāgadugham varṣiṣṭhāya nākāya pariveṣṭāram
translated: For truth, the thief-catcher; for the slaying of foes, the spy; for discrimination, the door-keeper; for observation, the superintendent; for childhood, the attendant; for greatness, the circumbulator; for love, the sweet-speeched; for safety, the horse-leader; for the heavenly world, the milk-distributor; for the highest heaven, the encircler.

original: manyave 'yastāpaṃ krodhāya nisaraṃ yogāya yoktāram śokāyābhisartāraṃ kṣemāya vimoktāram utkūlebhyas triṣṭhinaṃ vapuṣe mānaskṛtam śīlāyāñjanīkārīṃ nirṛtyai kośakārīṃ yamāyāsūm //🔽yamāya yamasūm atharvabhyo 'vatokām saṃvatsarāya paryāyiṇīṃ parivatsarāyāvijātām idāvatsarāyātītvarīm idvatsarāyātiṣkadvarīṃ vatsarāya vijarjarām saṃvatsarāya paliknīm ṛbhubhyo 'jinasaṃdham sādhyebhyaś carmamnam //
analyzed: manyave yaḥ tāpam krodhāya nisaram yogāya yoktāram śokāya abhisartāram kṣemāya vimoktāram utkūlebhyaḥ triṣṭhinam vapuṣe mānaskṛtam śīlāya añjanīkārīm nirṛtyai kośa kārīm yamāya asūm  yamāya yamasūm atharvabhyaḥ vatokām saṃvatsarāya paryāyiṇīm parivatsarāya avijātām idāvatsarāya atītvarīm idvatsarāya atiṣkadvarīm vatsarāya vijarjarām saṃvatsarāya paliknīm ṛbhubhyaḥ jina saṃdham sādhyebhyaḥ carmamnam
translated: To Anger, the one who burns with pain; to Wrath, the one who spreads; to Yoga, the one who yokes; to Sorrow, the one who approaches; to Welfare, the one who releases; to the uneven places, the one who stands firm; to Beauty, the one who is honored; to Virtue, the one who acts with ointment; to Destruction, the one who makes the sheath; to Restraint, the one who makes the arrow.🔽To Restraint, the one who makes the arrow; to the Atharvas, the one who has no offspring; to the year that passes around, the one who goes in a circle; to the year that changes, the one who is not born; to the year that has passed, the one who goes beyond; to the year that is to come, the one who goes too far; to the year, the one who is worn out; to the year that passes around, the one who is covered with dust; to the Rbhus, the one who has a skin for a joint; to the Sadhyas, the one who has a skin for a covering.

original: sarebhyo dhaivaram upasthāvarābhyo dāśaṃ vaiśantābhyo baindaṃ naḍvalābhyaḥ śauṣkalaṃ pārāya mārgāram avarāya kevartaṃ tīrthebhya āndaṃ viṣamebhyo mainālam svanebhyaḥ parṇakaṃ guhābhyaḥ kirātam sānubhyo jambhakaṃ parvatebhyaḥ kimpūruṣam //
analyzed: sarebhyaḥ dhaivaram upasthāvarābhyaḥ dāśam vaiśantābhyaḥ baindam naḍvalābhyaḥ śauṣkalam pārāya mārgāram avarāya kevartam tīrthebhyaḥ āndam viṣamebhyaḥ mainālam svanebhyaḥ parṇakam guhābhyaḥ kirātam sānubhyaḥ jambhakam parvatebhyaḥ kimpūruṣam
translated: To the rivers, the Dhaivara; to the rivers that are near, the Dasha; to the Vaishanta rivers, the Bainda; to the Nadvala rivers, the Shaushkala; to the Paraya river, the Margara; to the lower river, the Kevarta; to the holy places, the Anda; to the uneven places, the Mainala; to the sounds, the Parnaka; to the caves, the Kirata; to the mountain slopes, the Jambhaka; to the mountains, the Kipurusa.

original: bībhatsāyai paulkasaṃ varṇāya hiraṇyakāraṃ tulāyai vāṇijaṃ paścādoṣāya glāvinaṃ viśvebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ sidhmalaṃ bhūtyai jāgaraṇam abhūtyai svapanam ārtyai janavādinaṃ vyṛddhyā apagalbham samśarāya pracchidam //
analyzed: bībhatsāyai paulkasam varṇāya hiraṇyakāram tulāyai vāṇijam paścādoṣāya glāvinam viśvebhyaḥ bhūtebhyaḥ sidhmalam bhūtyai jāgaraṇam abhūtyai svapanam ārtyai janavādinam vyṛddhyai apagalbham samśarāya pracchidam
translated: To Disgust, the gambler; to the Varna, the goldsmith; to the Balance, the merchant; to the Hindrance, the butcher; to all the beings, the leper; to Prosperity, the sleepless; to Misfortune, the sleeping; to Distress, the tale-bearer; to Failure, the timid; to the Assembly, the slanderer.

original: akṣarājāya kitavaṃ kṛtāyādinavadarśaṃ tretāyai kalpinaṃ dvāparāyādhikalpinam āskandāya sabhāsthāṇuṃ mṛtyave govyaccham antakāya goghātaṃ kṣudhe yo gāṃ vikṛntantaṃ bhikṣamāṇa upatiṣṭhati duṣkṛtāya carakācāryaṃ pāpmane sailagam //
analyzed: akṣa rājāya kitavam kṛtāya ādi nava darśam tretāyai kalpinam dvāparāya adhikalpinam āskandāya sabhāsthāṇum mṛtyave govyaccham antakāya go ghātam kṣudhe yaḥ gām vikṛntantam bhikṣamāṇaḥ upatiṣṭhati duṣkṛtāya caraka ācāryam pāpmane sailagam
translated: To the Game of Dice, the cheat; to the New and Full Moon sacrifices, the hypocrite; to the Treta age, the schemer; to the Dvapara age, the super-schemer; to the Assault, the pillar of the assembly; to Death, the cow-thief; to the Destroyer, the cow-killer; to Hunger, he who stands by the man who is killing a cow for alms; to Evil, the teacher of wandering ascetics; to Sin, the mountaineer.

original: pratiśrutkāyā artanaṃ ghoṣāya bhaṣam antāya bahuvādinam anantāya mūkam śabdāyāḍambarāghātaṃ mahase vīṇāvādaṃ krośāya tūṇavadhmam avarasparāya śaṅkhadhmaṃ vanāya vatapam anyato'raṇyāya dāvapam //
analyzed: pratiśrutkāyāḥ artanam ghoṣāya bhaṣam antāya bahu vādinam anantāya mūkam śabdāya āḍambara āghātam mahase vīṇā vādam krośāya tūṇa vadhmam avarasparāya śaṅkha dhmam vanāya vatapam anya toraṇyāya dāvapam
translated: To the Echo, the beggar; to the Sound, the brayer; to the End, the much-talker; to the Endless, the dumb; to the Word, the beating of drums; to Greatness, the playing of the lute; to the Shout, the blowing of conches; to the Near and Far, the blowing of horns; to the Forest, the forest-fire; to the Other Forest, the wild-fire.

original: narmāya pumścalūm hasāya kāriṃ yādase śābalyāṃ grāmaṇyaṃ gaṇakam abhikrośakaṃ tān mahase vīṇāvādaṃ pāṇighnaṃ tūṇavadhmaṃ tān nṛtāyānandāya talavam //
analyzed: narmāya pumścalūm hasāya kārim yādase śābalyām grāmaṇyam gaṇakam abhikrośakam tān mahase vīṇā vādam pāṇi ghnam tūṇa vadhmam tān nṛtāya ānandāya talavam
translated: For pleasure, a woman who is fickle; for laughter, a maker of jokes; for prosperity, a village chief; for the village, a mathematician; for the assembly, a crier. For greatness, a vīṇā-player; for the hands, a drummer; for the lute, a flute-player. For dancing, for joy, a dancer.

original: agnaye pīvānaṃ pṛthivyai pīṭhasarpiṇaṃ vāyave cāṇḍālam antarikṣāya vamśanartinaṃ dive khalatim sūryāya haryakṣaṃ nakṣatrebhyaḥ kirmiraṃ candramase kilāsam ahne śuklaṃ piṅgākṣam rātryai kṛṣṇaṃ piṅgākṣam //
analyzed: agnaye pīvānam pṛthivyai pīṭha sarpiṇam vāyave cāṇḍālam antarikṣāya vamśa nartinam dive khalatim sūryāya hari akṣam nakṣatrebhyaḥ kirmiram candramase kilāsam ahne śuklam piṅga akṣam rātryai kṛṣṇam piṅga akṣam
translated: To Agni, a fat one; to Earth, one with a seat of clarified butter; to Vāyu, a Cāṇḍāla; to the atmosphere, a dancer; to Heaven, a bald one; to the Sun, one with tawny eyes; to the stars, a Kirmīra; to the Moon, a leper; to the day, a white one with tawny eyes; to the night, a black one with tawny eyes.

original: ataitān aṣṭau virūpān ā labhate 'tidīrghaṃ cātihrasvaṃ cātisthūlaṃ cātikṛśaṃ cātiśuklaṃ cātikṛṣṇaṃ cātikulvaṃ cātilomaśaṃ ca / aśūdrā abrāhmaṇās te prājāpatyāḥ / māgadhaḥ pumścalī kitavaḥ klībo 'śūdrā abrāhmaṇās te prājāpatyāḥ //
analyzed: atas etān aṣṭau virūpān ā labhate ti dīrgham ca ati hrasvam ca ati sthūlam ca ati kṛśam ca ati śuklam ca ati kṛṣṇam ca ati kulvam ca ati lomaśam ca
translated: He offers these eight deformed ones: one too tall, one too short, one too fat, one too thin, one too white, one too black, one too hairy, one too bald. They are non-Śūdras, non-Brāhmaṇas, belonging to Prajāpati. A Māgadha, a womanizer, a gambler, a eunuch, non-Śūdras, non-Brāhmaṇas, belonging to Prajāpati.

original: sahasraśīrṣā puruṣaḥ sahasrākṣaḥ sahasrapāt / sa bhūmim sarvata spṛtvāty atiṣṭhad daśāṅgulam //
analyzed: sahasra śīrṣā puruṣaḥ sahasra akṣaḥ sahasra pād    sa bhūmim sarvatas spṛtvā ati atiṣṭhat daśa aṅgulam
translated: The Person has a thousand heads, a thousand eyes, a thousand feet. He pervades this earth on all sides and extends out ten fingers.

original: puruṣa evedam sarvaṃ yad bhūtaṃ yac ca bhāvyam / utāmṛtatvasyeśāno yad annenātirohati //
analyzed: puruṣaḥ eva idam sarvam yat bhūtam yat ca bhāvyam   uta amṛta tvasya īśānaḥ yat annena atirohati
translated: This All is verily only the Person, what hath been and what yet shall be. He is the Lord of immortality which is above this food.

original: etāvān asya mahimāto jyāyāmś ca pūruṣaḥ / pādo 'sya viśvā bhūtāni tripād asyāmṛtaṃ divi //
analyzed: etāvān asya mahimā atas jyāyān ca pūruṣaḥ   pādaḥ u sya viśvā bhūtāni tri pād asya amṛtam divi
translated: So great is his greatness. Greater than he is the Person. In him the worlds rest, three are his feet, and one is above the immortal in heaven.

original: tripād ūrdhva ud ait puruṣaḥ pādo 'syehābhavat punaḥ / tato viṣvaṅ vy akrāmat sāśanānaśane abhi //
analyzed: tri pād ūrdhvaḥ ud ait puruṣaḥ pādaḥ u sya iha abhavat punar   tatas viṣvaṅ vi akrāmat sa aśana anaśane abhi
translated: The Person, three-footed, went upwards. One foot of him is here again. Thence he strode out in all directions, over what eateth food and what eateth not.

original: tasmād virāḍ ajāyata virājo adhi pūruṣaḥ / sa jāto aty aricyata paścād bhūmim atho puraḥ //
analyzed: tasmāt virāj ajāyata virājaḥ adhi pūruṣaḥ   sa jātaḥ ati aricyata paścāt bhūmim atha u puras
translated: From him was born Virāj. From Virāj was born Purusha. When he was born, he filled the whole of this world. He extended beyond it on every side, even as a wheel does its circumference.

original: tasmād yajñāt sarvahutaḥ sambhṛtaṃ pṛṣadājyam / paśūms tāmś cakre vāyavyān āraṇyā grāmyāś ca ye //
analyzed: tasmāt yajñāt sarva hutaḥ sambhṛtam pṛṣadājyam   paśūm tām cakre vāyavyān āraṇyāḥ grāmyāḥ ca ye
translated: From that sacrifice, offered in every way, the speckled butter was produced. He made those animals, the wild and the domestic, which are the portions of Vāyu.

original: tasmād yajñāt sarvahuta ṛcaḥ sāmāni jajñire / chandāmsi jajñire tasmād yajus tasmād ajāyata //
analyzed: tasmāt yajñāt sarva hutaḥ ṛcaḥ sāmāni jajñire chandāmsi jajñire tasmāt yajuḥ tasmāt ajāyata
translated: From that sacrifice, offered in every way, the Ṛc verses and the Sāman chants were born. The metres were born from him. From him the Yajuṣ was born.

original: tasmād aśvā ajāyanta ye ke cobhayādataḥ / gāvo ha jajñire tasmāt tasmāj jātā ajāvayaḥ //
analyzed: tasmāt aśvāḥ ajāyanta ye ke ca ubhaya adataḥ    gāvaḥ ha jajñire tasmāt tasmāt jātāḥ aja avayaḥ
translated: From him were born the horses, and all the animals with two rows of teeth. The cows were born from him. From him were born the goats and sheep.

original: taṃ yajñaṃ barhiṣi praukṣan puruṣaṃ jātam agrataḥ / tena devā ayajanta sādhyā ṛṣayaś ca ye //
analyzed: tam yajñam barhiṣi praukṣan puruṣam jātam agratas    tena devāḥ ayajanta sādhyāḥ ṛṣayaḥ ca ye
translated: They strewed that sacrifice on the sacred grass, the Person who was born in the beginning. With him the gods, the Sadhyas, and the Rishis worshipped.

original: yat puruṣaṃ vy adadhuḥ katidhā vy akalpayan / mukhaṃ kim asya kau bāhū kā ūrū pādā ucyete //
analyzed: yat puruṣam vi adadhuḥ katidhā vi akalpayan mukham kim asya kau bāhū kau ūrū pādau ucyete
translated: When they divided the Person how many portions did they make? What was he in the beginning? What do they call him now?

original: brāhmaṇo 'sya mukham āsīd bāhū rājanyaḥ kṛtaḥ / ūrū tad asya yad vaiśyaḥ padbhyām śūdro ajāyata //
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ sya mukham āsīt bāhū rājanyaḥ kṛtaḥ   ūrū tat asya yat vaiśyaḥ padbhyām śūdraḥ ajāyata
translated: The Brahman was his mouth, of both arms was the Rajanya made. His thighs became the Vaisya, from his feet the Sudra was born.

original: candramā manaso jātaś cakṣoḥ sūryo ajāyata / śrotrād vāyuś ca prāṇaś ca mukhād agnir ajāyata //
analyzed: candramāḥ manasaḥ jātaḥ cakṣoḥ sūryaḥ ajāyata    śrotrāt vāyuḥ ca prāṇaḥ ca mukhāt agniḥ ajāyata
translated: The moon was born from his mind, from his eye was born the sun. From his ear the wind and the breath, from his mouth was born Agni.

original: nābhyā āsīd antarikṣam śīrṣṇo dyauḥ sam avartata / padbhyāṃ bhūmir diśaḥ śrotrāt tathā lokām akalpayan //
analyzed: nābhyāḥ āsīt antarikṣam śīrṣṇaḥ dyauḥ sam avartata   padbhyām bhūmiḥ diśaḥ śrotrāt tathā akalpayan
translated: From his navel came the atmosphere, from his head the sky was formed. From his feet the earth, from his ear the quarters, thus they formed the worlds.

original: yat puruṣeṇa haviṣā devā yajñam atanvata / vasanto 'syāsīd ājyaṃ grīṣma idhmaḥ śarad dhaviḥ //
analyzed: yat puruṣeṇa haviṣā devāḥ yajñam atanvata    vasantaḥ sya āsīt ājyam grīṣmaḥ idhmaḥ śarad haviḥ
translated: When the gods spread the sacrifice with the Person as the sacrificial offering, the spring was his ghee, the summer his fuel, the autumn his oblation.

original: saptāsyāsan paridhayas triḥ sapta samidhaḥ kṛtāḥ / devā yad yajñaṃ tanvānā abadhnan puruṣaṃ paśum //
analyzed: sapta asya āsan paridhayaḥ tris sapta samidhaḥ kṛtāḥ   devāḥ yat yajñam tanvānāḥ abadhnan puruṣam paśum
translated: He had seven enclosing sticks, three times seven brands were made, when the gods, spreading the sacrifice, bound the Person as the sacrificial animal.

original: yajñena yajñam ayajanta devās tāni dharmāṇi prathamāny āsan / te ha nākaṃ mahimānaḥ sacanta yatra pūrve sādhyāḥ santi devāḥ //
analyzed: yajñena yajñam ayajanta devāḥ tāni dharmāṇi prathamāni āsan    te ha nākam mahimānaḥ sacanta yatra pūrve sādhyāḥ santi devāḥ
translated: The gods worshipped sacrifice with sacrifice; those were the earliest ordinances. They, the great ones, attend on the vault, where the Sadhyas, the ancient gods, are.

original: adbhyaḥ sambhṛtaḥ pṛthivyai rasāc ca viśvakarmaṇaḥ sam avartatāgre / tasya tvaṣṭā vidadhad rūpam eti tan martyasya devatvam ājānam agre //
analyzed: adbhyaḥ sambhṛtaḥ pṛthivyai rasāt ca viśva karmaṇaḥ sam avartata agre   tasya tvaṣṭā vidadhat rūpam eti tat martyasya deva tvam ājānam agre
translated: He who was produced from the waters, from the earth, from the essence, and from Visvakarman, in the beginning. Tvashtri, giving him form, approaches him. That is the mortal's birth to godhead in the beginning.

original: vedāham etaṃ puruṣaṃ mahāntam ādityavarṇaṃ tamasaḥ parastāt / tam eva viditvāti mṛtyum eti nānyaḥ panthā vidyate 'yanāya //
analyzed: veda aham etam puruṣam mahāntam āditya varṇam tamasaḥ parastāt   tam eva viditvā ati mṛtyum eti na anyaḥ panthāḥ vidyate yanāya
translated: I know this great Person, of the color of the sun, beyond darkness. Having known him alone, one goes beyond death. There is no other path to go.

original: prajāpatiś carati garbhe antar ajāyamāno bahudhā vi jāyate / tasya yoniṃ pari paśyanti dhīrās tasmin ha tasthur bhuvanāni viśvā //
analyzed: prajāpatiḥ carati garbhe antar a jāyamānaḥ bahudhā vi jāyate    tasya yonim pari paśyanti dhīrāḥ tasmin ha tasthuḥ bhuvanāni viśvā
translated: Prajapati moves within the womb, unborn, he is born in many ways. The wise ones look around his birthplace. In him are established all the worlds.

original: yo devebhya ātapati yo devānāṃ purohitaḥ / pūrvo yo devebhyo jāto namo rucāya brāhmaye //
analyzed: yaḥ devebhyaḥ ātapati yaḥ devānām purohitaḥ   pūrvaḥ yaḥ devebhyaḥ jātaḥ namaḥ rucāya brāhmaye
translated: He who shines upon the gods, who is the priest of the gods, who was born before the gods, homage to the radiant one, to the Brahmanic one.

original: rucaṃ brāhmyaṃ janayanto devā agre tad abruvan / yas tvaivaṃ brāhmaṇo vidyāt tasya devā asan vaśe //
analyzed: rucam brāhmyam janayantaḥ devāḥ agre tat abruvan    yaḥ tvā evam brāhmaṇaḥ vidyāt tasya devāḥ asan vaśe
translated: The gods, producing the Brahmanic lustre in the beginning, said this: He who knows thus, the gods would be under his control.

original: śrīś ca te lakṣmīś ca patnyāv ahorātre pārśve nakṣatrāṇi rūpam aśvinau vyāttām / iṣṇann iṣāṇāmuṃ ma iṣāṇa sarvalokaṃ ma iṣāṇa //
analyzed: śrīḥ ca te lakṣmīḥ ca patnyau ahar rātre pārśve nakṣatrāṇi rūpam aśvinau vyāttām    iṣṇan iṣāṇa amum me iṣāṇa sarva lokam me iṣāṇa
translated: And Sri and Lakshmi are his wives, day and night are his sides, the stars are his form, the Ashvins are his openers, he is the one who seeks, he seeks this, he seeks all worlds for me.

original: tad evāgnis tad ādityas tad vāyus tad u candramāḥ / tad eva śukraṃ tad brahma tā āpaḥ sa prajāpatiḥ //
analyzed: tat eva agniḥ tat ādityaḥ tat vāyuḥ tat u candramāḥ   tat eva śukram tat brahma tāḥ āpaḥ sa prajāpatiḥ
translated: That is indeed Agni, that is indeed Aditya, that is indeed Vayu, that is indeed the moon. That is indeed the bright one, that is Brahman, those are the waters, that is Prajapati.

original: sarve nimeṣā jajñire vidyutaḥ puruṣād adhi / nainam ūrdhvaṃ na tiryañcaṃ na madhye pari jagrabhat //
analyzed: sarve nimeṣāḥ jajñire vidyutaḥ puruṣāt adhi   na enam ūrdhvam na tiryañcam na madhye pari jagrabhat
translated: All the twinklings of an eye were born from the Purusha. The lightning is from the Purusha. He has not grasped it above, not across, not in the middle.

original: na tasya pratimā asti yasya nāma mahad yaśaḥ / hiraṇyagarbha ity eṣaḥ / mā mā himsīd ity eṣā / yasmān na jāta ity eṣa //
analyzed: na tasya pratimā asti yasya nāma mahat yaśaḥ   hiraṇya garbhaḥ iti eṣaḥ   mā mā himsīt iti eṣā    yasmāt na jātaḥ iti eṣa
translated: He has no image, he whose name is great fame. This is Hiranyagarbha. This is May he not injure me. This is From whom nothing is born.

original: eṣo ha devaḥ pradiśo 'nu sarvāḥ pūrvo ha jātaḥ sa u garbhe antaḥ / sa eva jātaḥ sa janiṣyamāṇaḥ pratyaṅ janās tiṣthati sarvatomukhaḥ //
analyzed: eṣaḥ ha devaḥ pradiśaḥ nu sarvāḥ pūrvaḥ ha jātaḥ saḥ u garbhe antar    saḥ eva jātaḥ sa janiṣyamāṇaḥ pratyaṅ janāḥ tiṣthati sarvatomukhaḥ
translated: This indeed is the god who pervades all the directions. Born before, he is in the womb within. He alone is born, he is to be born. He stands facing all directions, facing all people.

original: yasmāj jātaṃ na purā kiṃ canaiva ya ābabhūva bhuvanāni viśvā / prajāpatiḥ prajayā samrarāṇas trīṇi jyotīmṣi sacate sa aiḍaśī //🔽yena dyaur ugrā pṛthivī ca dṛḍhā yena sva stabhitaṃ yena nākaḥ / yo antarikṣe rajaso vimānaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema //
analyzed: yasmāt jātam na purā kim cana eva yaḥ ābabhūva bhuvanāni viśvā    prajāpatiḥ prajayā samrarāṇaḥ trīṇi jyotīmṣi sacate saḥ aiḍaśī  yena dyauḥ ugrā pṛthivī ca dṛḍhā yena svar stabhitam yena nākaḥ     yaḥ antarikṣe rajasaḥ vimānaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
translated: Since nothing whatever was born before him, he who hath become the supporter of all existing things, Prajapati, rejoicing in offspring, is associated with the three lights, he who is most wise.🔽To what god shall we offer with oblation, by whom the terrible sky and the firm earth are held, by whom the vault is firmly established, he who is in the atmosphere, the measurer of the region?

original: yaṃ krandasī avasā tastabhāne abhy aikṣetāṃ manasā rejamāne / yatrādhi sūra udito vibhāti kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema //
analyzed: yam krandasī avasā tastabhāne abhī aikṣetām manasā rejamāne     yatra adhi sūraḥ uditaḥ vibhāti kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
translated: To what god shall we offer with oblation, whom the two worlds, when they are firmly established, look upon with favour, when they are trembling with hope, where the sun shines when he hath risen?

original: āpo ha yad bṛhatīḥ / yaś cid āpaḥ //
analyzed: āpaḥ ha yat bṛhatīḥ yaḥ cit āpaḥ
translated: The waters, indeed, are the great ones. He who knows the waters...

original: venas tat paśyan nihitaṃ guhā sad yatra viśvaṃ bhavaty ekanīḍam / tasminn idam saṃ ca vi caiti sarvam sa otaḥ protaś ca vibhūḥ prajāsu //
analyzed: venaḥ tat paśyan nihitam guhā sat yatra viśvam bhavati eka nīḍam    tasmin idam sam ca vi ca eti sarvam saḥ otaḥ protaḥ ca vibhūḥ prajāsu
translated: Vena, beholding that which is laid up in the cave, the one nest of all that is, in which all things are contained, in that (all) this is collected together and dispersed, he is the warp and woof, the all-pervading one among creatures.

original: pra tad voced amṛtaṃ nu vidvān gandharvo dhāma vibhṛtaṃ guhā sat / trīṇi padāni nihitā guhāsya yas tāni veda sa pituḥ pitāsat //
analyzed: pra tat vocet amṛtam nu vidvān gandharvaḥ dhāma vibhṛtam guhā sat  / trīṇi padāni nihitā guhā asya yaḥ tāni veda sa pituḥ pitā asat
translated: The Gandharva, knowing that immortal state, the abode distributed in secret, the three steps laid up in his cave, he who knows them is the father of the father.

original: sa no bandhur janitā sa vidhātā dhāmāni veda bhuvanāni viśvā / yatra devā amṛtam ānaśānās tṛtīye dhāmann adhy airayanta //🔽parītya bhūtāni parītya lokān parītya sarvāḥ pradiśo diśaś ca / upasthāya prathamajām ṛtasyātmanātmānam abhi saṃ viveśa //
analyzed: sa naḥ bandhuḥ janitā sa vidhātā dhāmāni veda bhuvanāni viśvā    yatra devāḥ amṛtam ānaśānāḥ tṛtīye dhāman adhi airayanta  parītya bhūtāni parītya lokān parītya sarvāḥ pradiśaḥ diśaḥ ca     upasthāya prathama jām ṛtasya ātmanā ātmānam abhi sam viveśa
translated: He is our kinsman, our progenitor, our ordainer, who knows all the abodes and all the worlds.🔽Having gone round the beings, having gone round the worlds, having gone round all the quarters and the intermediate directions, having approached the firstborn of truth, he entered into himself by himself.

original: pari dyāvāpṛthivī sadya itvā pari lokān pari diśaḥ pari svaḥ / ṛtasya tantuṃ vitataṃ vicṛtya tad apaśyat tad abhavat tad āsīt //
analyzed: pari dyāvāpṛthivī sadyas itvā pari lokān pari diśaḥ pari svar    ṛtasya tantum vitatam vicṛtya tat apaśyat tat abhavat tat āsīt
translated: Having gone round heaven and earth in a moment, having gone round the worlds, having gone round the quarters and the heavenly world, having unraveled the extended thread of truth, he saw that, he became that, he was that.

original: sadasas patim adbhutaṃ priyam indrasya kāmyam / saniṃ medhām ayāsiṣamm svāhā //
analyzed: sadasaḥ patim adbhutam priyam indrasya kāmyam    sanim medhām ayāsiṣam svāhā
translated: The lord of the assembly, the wondrous one, dear to Indra, the fulfiller of desires, I have sought the wise one, svāhā.

original: yāṃ medhāṃ devagaṇāḥ pitaraś copāsate / tayā mām adya medhayāgne medhāvinaṃ kuru svāhā //
analyzed: yām medhām deva gaṇāḥ pitaraḥ ca upāsate    tayā mām adya medhayā agne medhāvinam kuru svāhā
translated: The wisdom which the hosts of gods and the ancestors attend upon, by that wisdom, O Agni, make me wise today, svāhā.

original: medhāṃ me varuṇo dadātu medhām agniḥ prajāpatiḥ / medhām indras ca vāyuś ca medhāṃ dhātā dadātu me svāhā //
analyzed: medhām me varuṇaḥ dadātu medhām agniḥ prajāpatiḥ   medhām indraḥ ca vāyuḥ ca medhām dhātā dadātu me svāhā
translated: May Varuna grant me wisdom, may Agni and Prajapati, may Indra and Vayu, may Dhatr grant me wisdom, svāhā.

original: idaṃ me brahma ca kṣatraṃ cobhe śriyam aśnutām / mayi devā dadhatu śriyam uttamāṃ tasyai te svāhā //
analyzed: idam me brahma ca kṣatram ca ubhe śriyam aśnutām    mayi devāḥ dadhatu śriyam uttamām tasyai te svāhā
translated: May this my Brahman and my Kshatriya both enjoy prosperity. May the Gods bestow on me the highest prosperity. To that prosperity of thine, Hail!🔽These my imperishable ploughs, my ploughs with smoking plough-shares, my purifying fires,

original: asyājarāso damām aritrā arcaddhūmāso agnayaḥ pāvakāḥ / śvitīcayaḥ śvātrāso bhuraṇyavo vanarṣado vāyavo na somāḥ //
analyzed: asya ajarāsaḥ damām aritrā arcat dhūmāsaḥ agnayaḥ pāvakāḥ śvitīcayaḥ śvātrāsaḥ bhuraṇyavaḥ vanarṣadaḥ vāyavaḥ na somāḥ
translated: My white-maned, my tawny-coloured, my active, my rain-showering, my wind-like Soma-pressing (waters),

original: harayo dhumaketavo vātajūtā upa dyavi / yatante vṛthag agnayaḥ //
analyzed: harayaḥ dhuma ketavaḥ vāta jūtāḥ upa dyavi    yatante vṛthak agnayaḥ
translated: The tawny ones, the smoke-bannered, urged on by the wind, strive in the sky, the fires in their own places.

original: yajā no mitrāvaruṇā yajā devām ṛtaṃ bṛhat / agne yakṣi svaṃ damam //
analyzed: yaja naḥ mitrāvaruṇā yaja devām ṛtam bṛhat    agne yakṣi svam damam
translated: Worship for us Mitra and Varuna, worship the Gods, the lofty Law, O Agni, worship in thy own abode.

original: yukṣvā hi devahūtamām aśvām agne rathīr iva / ni hotā pūrvyaḥ sadaḥ //
analyzed: yukṣvā hi deva hūtamām aśvām agne rathīḥ iva    ni hotā pūrvyaḥ sadaḥ
translated: Yoke, O Agni, as a charioteer his two horses, thy two that best invite the Gods. Sit as Hotar in thy wonted place.

original: dve virūpe carataḥ svarthe anyānyā vatsam upa dhāpayete / harir anyasyāṃ bhavati svadhāvāñ chukro anyasyāṃ dadṛśe suvarcāḥ //
analyzed: dve virūpe carataḥ su arthe anyā anyā vatsam upa dhāpayete   hariḥ anyasyām bhavati svadhāvān śukraḥ anyasyām dadṛśe su varcāḥ
translated: Two unlike ones move on their way, each to its own goal: each one causes its young one to drink. In one the tawny one is strong with his own power; in the other the bright one is seen with fair radiance.

original: ayam iha prathamo dhāyi dhātṛbhir hotā yajiṣṭho adhvareṣv īḍyaḥ / yam apnavāno bhṛgavo virurucur vaneṣu citraṃ vibhvaṃ viśeviśe //
analyzed: ayam iha prathamaḥ dhāyi dhātṛbhiḥ hotā yajiṣṭhaḥ adhvareṣu īḍyaḥ   yam apnavānaḥ bhṛgavaḥ virurucuḥ vaneṣu citram vibhvam viśeviśe
translated: This one was first established here by the establishers, the Hotar, most to be worshipped at sacrifices, to be glorified. Him the Apnavâna Bhr̥igus have made to shine, the wondrous, the all-pervading, in every house.

original: trīṇi śatā trī sahasrāṇy agniṃ trimśac ca devā nava cāsaparyan / aukṣan ghṛtair astṛṇan barhir asmā ād id dhotāraṃ ny asādayanta //
analyzed: trīṇi śatā trī sahasrāṇi agnim trimśat ca devāḥ nava ca asaparyan    aukṣan ghṛtaiḥ astṛṇan barhiḥ asmai āt id hotāram ni asādayanta
translated: Three hundred, three thousand, and thirty-nine gods have attended Agni. They have anointed him with ghee, have strewn the sacred grass for him, and have placed him as Hotar.

original: mūrdhānaṃ divo aratiṃ pṛthivyā vaiśvānaram ṛta ā jātam agnim / kavim samrājam atithiṃ janānām āsann ā pātraṃ janayanta devāḥ //
analyzed: mūrdhānam divaḥ aratim pṛthivyāḥ vaiśvānaram ṛte ā jātam agnim    kavim samrājam atithim janānām āsan ā pātram janayanta devāḥ
translated: The head of the sky, the messenger of the earth, Agni Vaiśvānara, born in the womb of truth, the wise, the emperor, the guest of men, the gods have generated him as a vessel near at hand.

original: agnir vṛtrāṇi jaṅghanad draviṇasyur vipanyayā / samiddhaḥ śukra āhutaḥ //
analyzed: agniḥ vṛtrāṇi jaṅghanat draviṇasyuḥ vipanyayā samiddhaḥ śukraḥ āhutaḥ
translated: Agni, the seeker of wealth, with his own path, shall crush the Vr̥itras, kindled, bright, and worshipped.

original: viśvebhiḥ somyaṃ madhv agna indreṇa vāyunā / pibā mitrasya dhāmabhiḥ //🔽ā yad iṣe nṛpatiṃ teja ānaṭ śuci reto niṣiktaṃ dyaur abhīke / agniḥ śardham anavadyaṃ yuvānam svādhyaṃ janayat sūdayac ca //
analyzed: viśvebhiḥ somyam madhu agne indreṇa vāyunā    pibā mitrasya dhāmabhiḥ  ā yat iṣe nṛpatim tejaḥ ānaṭ śuci retaḥ niṣiktam dyauḥ abhīke    agniḥ śardham anavadyam yuvānam svādhyam janayat sūdayat ca
translated: With all the gods, with Indra, with Vâyu, drink thou the Soma-mingled meath, O Agni, with the regions of the Friend.🔽When he hath come to food, the Lord of men, to splendour, pure seed hath Dyaus deposited in the womb. Agni hath generated, hath produced the youthful blameless troop, the well-born one.

original: agne śardha mahate saubhagāya tava dyumnāny uttamāni santu / saṃ jāspatyam suyamam ā kṛṇuṣva śatrūyatām abhi tiṣṭhā mahāmsi //
analyzed: agne śardha mahate saubhagāya tava dyumnāni uttamāni santu   sam jāspatyam suyamam ā kṛṇuṣva śatrūyatām abhi tiṣṭhā
translated: O Agni, strive for great felicity: let thy most excellent glories be exalted. Make thou our sway easy to govern: overcome the great hostilities of our foes.

original: tvām hi mandratamam arkaśokair vavṛmahe mahi naḥ śroṣy agne / indraṃ na tvā śavasā devatā vāyuṃ pṛṇanti rādhasā nṛtamāḥ //
analyzed: tvām hi mandratamam arka śokaiḥ vavṛmahe mahi naḥ śroṣi agne    indram na tvā śavasā devatā vāyum pṛṇanti rādhasā nṛtamāḥ
translated: For we have chosen thee, O Agni, most delightful with the sorrows of the sun: be thou a great hearer for us. The most truthful deities, O God, strengthen thee in power, as in bounty, like Indra, like Vâyu.

original: tve agne svāhuta priyāsaḥ santu sūrayaḥ / yantāro ye maghavāno janānām ūrvān dayanta gonām //
analyzed: tve agne su āhuta priyāsaḥ santu sūrayaḥ   yantāraḥ ye maghavānaḥ janānām ūrvān dayanta gonām
translated: To thee, O Agni, well-worshipped, let the princes be most dear, the bounteous lords of men, who give away the broad pastures of the kine.

original: śrudhi śrutkarṇa vahnibhir devair agne sayāvabhiḥ / ā sīdantu barhiṣi mitro aryamā prātaryāvāṇo adhvaram //
analyzed: śrudhi śrut karṇa vahnibhiḥ devaiḥ agne sa yāvabhiḥ    ā sīdantu barhiṣi mitraḥ aryamā prātaryāvāṇaḥ adhvaram
translated: Hear, thou with ears to hear, O Agni, with the Gods who are to be invoked, with the most recent. Let Mitra, Aryaman, the early-faring (Gods) sit on the sacred grass.

original: viśveṣām aditir yajñiyānāṃ viśveṣām atithir mānuṣāṇām / agnir devānām ava āvṛṇānaḥ sumṛḍīko bhavatu jātavedāḥ //
analyzed: viśveṣām aditiḥ yajñiyānām viśveṣām atithiḥ mānuṣāṇām    agniḥ devānām avaḥ āvṛṇānaḥ su mṛḍīkaḥ bhavatu jātavedāḥ
translated: The common friend of all who are to be worshipped, the guest of all men, Agni, the God, the all-embracing. May Jâtavedas be propitious unto us.

original: maho agneḥ samidhānasya śarmaṇy anāgā mitre varuṇe svastaye / śreṣṭhe syāma savituḥ savīmani tad devānām avo adyā vṛṇīmahe //
analyzed: mahaḥ agneḥ samidhānasya śarmaṇi anāgāḥ mitre varuṇe svastaye   śreṣṭhe syāma savituḥ savīmani tat devānām avaḥ adyā vṛṇīmahe
translated: In the great shelter of enkindled Agni, free from all sin, in Mitra, in Varuna, for bliss, in the highest favour of the bounteous Savitar, that grace of the Gods we crave this day.

original: āpaś cit pipyu staryo na gāvo nakṣann ṛtaṃ jaritāras ta indra / yāhi vāyur na niyuto no acchā tvam hi dhībhir dayase vi vājān //
analyzed: āpaḥ cit pipyuḥ staryaḥ na gāvaḥ nakṣan ṛtam jaritāraḥ te indra    yāhi vāyuḥ na niyutaḥ naḥ acchā tvam hi dhībhiḥ dayase vi vājān
translated: Even the waters swell like mares and cows: the singers have attained to truth, O Indra. Come to us with thy teams as with the winds, for thou with hymns bestowest ample wealth.

original: gāva upāvatāvataṃ mahī yajñasya rapsudā / ubhā karṇā hiraṇyayā //
analyzed: gāvaḥ upāvata avatam mahī yajñasya rapsu dā    ubhā karṇā hiraṇyayā
translated: The two great cows have come to help, the two who cleanse the sacrifice, the two who are to be worshipped.🔽What today, when the sun has risen, Mitra, Aryaman,

original: yad adya sūra udite 'nāgā mitro aryamā / suvāti savitā bhagaḥ //
analyzed: yat adya sūre udite nāgāḥ mitraḥ aryamā    suvāti savitā bhagaḥ
translated: Savitar, Bhaga, have sent forth,

original: ā sute siñcata śriyam rodasyor abhiśriyam / rasā dadhīta vṛṣabham //
analyzed: ā sute siñcata śriyam rodasyoḥ abhiśriyam   rasā dadhīta vṛṣabham
translated: Pour out the glory of the two worlds, the ornament of heaven and earth. Let the juice take possession of the bull.

original: ātiṣṭhantaṃ pari viśve abhūṣañ chriyo vasānaś carati svarociḥ / mahat tad vṛṣṇo asurasya nāmā viśvarūpo amṛtāni tasthau //🔽pra vo mahe mandamānāyāndhaso 'rcā viśvānarāya viśvābhuve / indrasya yasya sumakham saho mahi śravo nṛmṇaṃ ca rodasī saparyataḥ //
analyzed: ātiṣṭhantam pari viśve abhūṣam chriyaḥ vasānaḥ carati sva rociḥ    mahat tat vṛṣṇaḥ asurasya nāma ā viśva rūpaḥ amṛtāni tasthau  pra vaḥ mahe mandamānāya andhasaḥ rcā viśvānarāya viśvābhuve      indrasya yasya su makham sahaḥ mahi śravaḥ nṛmṇam ca rodasī saparyataḥ
translated: All have rejoiced in him who hath approached, he moves in his own light clothed in glory. Great is the name of the strong Asura, he hath stood in the immortal forms of all.🔽To your great gladdening juice, to him who is all-ruler, all-possessor, I sing, whose is the fair sacrifice, whose is the great strength, whose is the glory and manly power which the two worlds honour.

original: bṛhann id idhma eṣāṃ bhūri śastaṃ pṛthuḥ svaruḥ / yeṣām indro yuvā sakhā //
analyzed: bṛhan id idhmaḥ eṣām bhūri śastam pṛthuḥ svaruḥ    yeṣām indraḥ yuvā sakhā
translated: Great is their fuel, great their praise, great their stake, whose friend is Indra, the young.

original: indrehi matsy andhaso viśvebhiḥ somaparvabhiḥ / mahām abhiṣṭir ojasā //
analyzed: indra ihi matsi andhasaḥ viśvebhiḥ soma parvabhiḥ   mahām abhiṣṭiḥ ojasā
translated: Come to me, O Indra, with the juice, with all the Soma feasts, the great protector with might.

original: indro vṛtram avṛṇoc chardhanītiḥ pra māyinām aminād varpaṇītiḥ / ahan vyamsam uśadhag vaneṣv āvir dhenā akṛṇod rāmyāṇām //
analyzed: indraḥ vṛtram avṛṇot śardha nītiḥ pra māyinām amināt varpaṇītiḥ    ahan vyamsam uśadhak vaneṣu āvis dhenāḥ akṛṇot rāmyāṇām
translated: Indra, with conquering might, hath compassed Vritra round: he, with his wondrous power, hath overcome the wiles. The greedy God hath slain the foe in woods and groves, and made the milch-kine of the forest manifest.

original: kutas tvam indra māhinaḥ sann eko yāsi satpate kiṃ ta itthā / saṃ pṛcchase samarāṇaḥ śubhānair voces tan no harivo yat te asme //
analyzed: kutas tvam indra māhinaḥ san ekaḥ yāsi satpate kim te itthā sam pṛcchase samarāṇaḥ śubhānaiḥ voceḥ tat naḥ harivas yat te asme
translated: Whence, Indra, comest thou, thou who art mighty, alone, O Lord of the brave? What is thy purpose? Thou meetest the bright ones in the conflict. Declare that to us, O thou who hast bay steeds, which thou hast here among us.🔽Indra, who is great in strength,🔽never art thou contemptible,

original: mahām indro ya ojasā / kadā cana starīr asi / kadā cana pra yucchasi //
analyzed: mahām indraḥ yaḥ ojasā    kadā cana starīḥ asi    kadā cana pra yucchasi
translated: never art thou remiss.🔽Let those thy people, O Indra, rejoice in the ample pasture which they long to reach,

original: ā tat ta indrāyavaḥ panantābhi ya ūrvaṃ gomantaṃ titṛtsān / sakṛtsvaṃ ye puruputrāṃ mahīm sahasradhārāṃ bṛhatīṃ dudukṣan //
analyzed: ā tat te indra āyavaḥ pananta abhi ye ūrvam gomantam titṛtsān   sakṛtsvam ye puru putrām mahīm sahasra dhārām bṛhatīm dudukṣan
translated: Who have milked the great, the mighty, the single cow, the earth, the mother of many sons, the bountiful, the thousand-flowing, the vast.

original: imāṃ te dhiyaṃ pra bhare maho mahīm asya stotre dhiṣaṇā yat ta ānaje / tam utsave ca prasave ca sāsahim indraṃ devāsaḥ śavasāmadann anu //
analyzed: imām te dhiyam pra bhare mahaḥ mahīm asya stotre dhiṣaṇā yat te ānaje    tam utsave ca prasave ca sāsahim indram devāsaḥ śavasā amadan anu
translated: This great hymn of praise I bring to thee, O mighty Indra, that it may win thee to this laud. In joy and in exertion they have delighted in Indra, the conqueror, the Gods have rejoiced in Indra's strength.

original: vibhrāḍ bṛhat pibatu somyaṃ madhv āyur dadhad yajñapatāv avihrutam / vātajūto yo abhirakṣati tmanā prajāḥ pupoṣa purudhā vi rājati //
analyzed: vibhrāj bṛhat pibatu somyam madhu āyuḥ dadhat yajñapatau a vihrutam   vāta jūtaḥ yaḥ abhirakṣati tmanā prajāḥ pupoṣa purudhā vi rājati
translated: May the mighty one drink the Soma-mingled draught, bestowing life on the lord of sacrifice without fail. He who, urged on by the wind, protects by his own power, has nourished the people and shines forth in many ways.

original: ud u tyaṃ jātavedasaṃ devaṃ vahanti ketavaḥ / dṛśe viśvāya sūryam svāhā //
analyzed: ud u tyam jātavedasam devam vahanti ketavaḥ   dṛśe viśvāya sūryam svāhā
translated: The rays carry upward that all-seeing god, the sun, to be seen by all. Hail!🔽By what eye, O purifying one, thou seest the moving one among the people,

original: yenā pāvaka cakṣasā bhuraṇyantaṃ janām anu / tvaṃ varuṇa paśyasi //
analyzed: yena pāvaka cakṣasā bhuraṇyantam janām anu    tvam varuṇa paśyasi
translated: O Varuna, thou seest.

original: daivyāv adhvaryū ā gatam rathena sūryatvacā / madhvā yajñam sam añjāthe //
analyzed: daivyau adhvaryū ā gatam rathena sūrya tvacā    madhvā yajñam sam añjāthe
translated: Come, O divine Adhvaryus, on your chariot with the sun's skin, and with sweetness consecrate the sacrifice.

original: taṃ pratnathā / ayaṃ venaḥ / citram devānām //
analyzed: tam pratnathā   ayam venaḥ citram devānām
translated: Him, as of old, this Vena, the wondrous one of the gods.

original: ā na iḍābhir vidathe suśasti viśvānaraḥ savitā deva etu / api yathā yuvāno matsathā no viśvaṃ jagad abhipitve manīṣā //
analyzed: ā naḥ iḍābhiḥ vidathe su śasti viśvānaraḥ savitā devaḥ etu    api yathā yuvānaḥ matsatha naḥ viśvam jagat abhipitve manīṣā
translated: May Savitar the god come to the assembly with the Ida offerings, praised by all men. As the young men delight in me, so may all the world's thoughts turn to me for support.🔽Whatever thou doest today, O Vritra-slayer, O sun, as thou goest up,

original: yad adya kac ca vṛtrahann udagā abhi sūrya / sarvaṃ tad indra te vaśe //
analyzed: yat adya kad ca vṛtrahan udagāḥ abhi sūrya       sarvam tat indra te vaśe
translated: all that, O Indra, is in thy power.

original: taraṇir viśvadarśato jyotiṣkṛd asi sūrya / viśvam ā bhāsi rocanam //
analyzed: taraṇiḥ viśva darśataḥ jyotiṣkṛt asi sūrya   viśvam ā bhāsi rocanam
translated: Thou art the swift one, O Surya, who shows all things, the maker of light. Thou dost illumine all the shining realm.

original: tat sūryasya devatvaṃ tan mahitvaṃ madhyā kartor vitatam saṃ jabhāra / yaded ayukta haritaḥ sadhasthād ād rātrī vāsas tanute simasmai //
analyzed: tat sūryasya deva tvam tat mahi tvam madhyā kartoḥ vitatam sam jabhāra    yadā id ayukta haritaḥ sadhasthāt āt rātrī vāsaḥ tanute simasmai
translated: That is the godhead of Surya, that is his greatness. He hath gathered in the midst of the work that was spread out. When he hath yoked the two bays from their station, then Night clothes a covering for him to wear.

original: tan mitrasya varuṇasyābhicakṣe sūryo rūpaṃ kṛṇute dyor upasthe / anantam anyad ruśad asya pājaḥ kṛṣṇam anyad dharitaḥ saṃ bharanti //🔽baṇ mahām asi sūrya baḍ āditya mahām asi / mahas te sato mahimā panasyate 'ddhā deva mahām asi //
analyzed: tat mitrasya varuṇasya abhicakṣe sūryaḥ rūpam kṛṇute dyoḥ upasthe    anantam anyat ruśat asya pājaḥ kṛṣṇam anyat haritaḥ sam bharanti  baṭ mahām asi sūrya baṭ āditya mahām asi    mahaḥ te sataḥ mahimā panasyate ddhā deva mahām asi
translated: That is the look of Mitra and Varuna. Surya assumes the form in the lap of the sky. One endless ruddy light of his they bring, and another black, they bring, the two bays.🔽Great art thou, O Surya, great, O Aditya, art thou. Great is the greatness of thy being. Yea, verily, O god, thou art great.

original: baṭ sūrya śravasā mahām asi satrā deva mahām asi / mahnā devānām asuryaḥ purohito vibhu jyotir adābhyam //
analyzed: baṭ sūrya śravasā mahām asi satrā deva mahām asi  / mahnā devānām asuryaḥ purohitaḥ vibhu jyotiḥ adābhyam
translated: Great art thou, O Surya, in fame. Ever, O god, thou art great. With the greatness of the gods, the Asura priest, the all-pervading light, art thou to be worshipped.

original: śrāyanta iva sūryaṃ viśved indrasya bhakṣata / vasūni jāte janamāna ojasā prati bhāgaṃ na dīdhima //
analyzed: śrāyantaḥ iva sūryam viśvā id indrasya bhakṣata    vasūni jāte janamāne ojasā prati bhāgam na dīdhima
translated: All men, as 'twere, incline to Surya, to enjoy all treasures which Indra hath gained by his might. Each one hath his own portion, each his thought.

original: adyā devā uditā sūryasya nir amhasaḥ pipṛtā nir avadyāt / tan no mitro varuṇo māmahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pṛthivī uta dyauḥ //
analyzed: adya devāḥ uditā sūryasya niḥ amhasaḥ pipṛta niḥ avadyāt     tat naḥ mitraḥ varuṇaḥ māmahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pṛthivī uta dyauḥ
translated: This day, O ye gods, when the sun hath risen, deliver us from trouble, from disgrace. This may Varuna and Mitra grant us, Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

original: ā kṛṣṇena rajasā vartamāno niveśayann amṛtaṃ martyaṃ ca / hiraṇyayena savitā rathenā devo yāti bhuvanāni paśyan //
analyzed: ā kṛṣṇena rajasā vartamānaḥ niveśayan amṛtam martyam ca  / hiraṇyayena savitā rathena ā devaḥ yāti bhuvanāni paśyan
translated: Moving in the dark-hued atmosphere, setting in order the immortal and the mortal, Savitar, the God, goes on his golden chariot, beholding the worlds.

original: pra vāvṛje suprayā barhir eṣām ā viśpatīva bīriṭa iyāte / viśām aktor uṣasaḥ pūrvahūtau vāyuḥ pūṣā svastaye niyutvān //
analyzed: pra vāvṛje su prayāḥ barhiḥ eṣām ā viśpatī iva bīriṭe iyāte     viśām aktoḥ uṣasaḥ pūrva hūtau vāyuḥ pūṣā svastaye niyutvān
translated: He has spread out their grass that is so fair to travel on; he has come like the lord of the people, at the invitation of the people, at the invitation of the dawn, Vayu and Pusan with their teams, for our welfare.

original: indravāyū bṛhaspatiṃ mitrāgniṃ pūṣaṇaṃ bhagam / ādityān mārutaṃ gaṇam //
analyzed: indra vāyū bṛhaspatim mitra agnim pūṣaṇam bhagam ādityān mārutam gaṇam
translated: Indra, Vayu, Brihaspati, Mitra, Agni, Pusan, Bhaga, the Adityas, the Marut host,

original: varuṇaḥ prāvitā bhuvan mitro viśvābhir ūtibhiḥ / karatāṃ naḥ surādhasaḥ //
analyzed: varuṇaḥ prāvitā bhuvat mitraḥ viśvābhiḥ ūtibhiḥ   karatām naḥ su rādhasaḥ
translated: Varuna has become the leader, Mitra with all his aids. May they make us givers of good gifts.

original: adhi na indreṣāṃ viṣṇo sajātyānām / itā maruto aśvinā //🔽taṃ pratnathā / ayaṃ venaḥ / ye devāsaḥ / ā na iḍābhiḥ / viśvebhiḥ somyaṃ madhu / omāsaś carṣaṇīdhṛtaḥ //
analyzed: adhi naḥ indra iṣām viṣṇo sajātyānām   ita marutaḥ aśvinā  tam pratnathā    ayam venaḥ   ye devāsaḥ ā naḥ iḍābhiḥ viśvebhiḥ somyam madhu    omāsaḥ carṣaṇī dhṛtaḥ
translated: On Indra, O ye of one accord, on Vishnu, on the Maruts, on the Asvins, on these, O ye of one accord,

original: agna indra varuṇa mitra devāḥ śardhaḥ pra yanta mārutota viṣṇo / ubhā nāsatyā rudro adha gnāḥ pūṣā bhagaḥ sarasvatī juṣanta //
analyzed: agne indra varuṇa mitra devāḥ śardhaḥ pra yanta māruta uta viṣṇo    ubhā nāsatyā rudraḥ adha gnāḥ pūṣā bhagaḥ sarasvatī juṣanta
translated: This Vena of old. Ye Gods. Come ye to us. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your aids. With all your

original: indrāgnī mitrāvaruṇāditim svaḥ pṛthivīṃ dyāṃ marutaḥ parvatām apaḥ / huve viṣṇuṃ pūṣaṇaṃ brahmaṇaspatiṃ bhagaṃ nu śamsam savitāram ūtaye //
analyzed: indra agnī mitrāvaruṇā aditim svar pṛthivīm dyām marutaḥ parvatām apaḥ    huve viṣṇum pūṣaṇam brahmaṇaspatim bhagam nu śamsam savitāram ūtaye
translated: I invoke Vishnu, Pusan, Brahmanaspati, Bhaga, and Samsa, and Savitar to help.🔽Rudras, with Mehanas, the mountains, in accord, in the slaying of Vrtra, in the call to aid,

original: asme rudrā mehanā parvatāso vṛtrahatye bharahūtau sajoṣāḥ / yaḥ śamsate stuvate dhāyi pajra indrajyeṣṭhā asmām avantu devāḥ //
analyzed: asme rudrāḥ mehanā parvatāsaḥ vṛtra hatye bhara hūtau sajoṣāḥ   yaḥ śamsate stuvate dhāyi pajraḥ indra jyeṣṭhāḥ asmām avantu devāḥ
translated: He who supports the one who praises, the one who sings, may the gods, with Indra foremost, help us.🔽Come hitherward today, ye Holy Ones: in your own home would I rejoice, fearing you.

original: arvāñco adyā bhavatā yajatrā ā vo hārdi bhayamāno vyayeyam / trādhvaṃ no devā nijuro vṛkasya trādhvaṃ kartād avapado yajatrāḥ //
analyzed: arvāñcaḥ adya bhavata yajatrāḥ ā vaḥ hārdi bhayamānaḥ vyayeyam    trādhvam naḥ devāḥ nijuraḥ vṛkasya trādhvam kartāt avapadaḥ yajatrāḥ
translated: Protect us, O ye Gods, from the treacherous wolf: protect us, O ye Holy Ones, from the pitfall.🔽All ye Maruts today, all ye who help, all ye be present, all the kindled fires,

original: viśve adya maruto viśva ūtī viśve bhavantv agnayaḥ samiddhāḥ / viśve no devā avasā gamantu viśvam astu draviṇaṃ vājo asme //
analyzed: viśve adya marutaḥ viśve ūtī viśve bhavantu agnayaḥ samiddhāḥ   viśve naḥ devāḥ avasā gamantu viśvam astu draviṇam vājaḥ asme
translated: May all the Gods come to us with help: may all wealth and strength be ours.🔽All ye Gods, hear this my invocation, ye who are in the atmosphere, ye who are in heaven,

original: viśve devāḥ śṛṇutemam havaṃ me ye antarikṣe ya upa dyavi ṣṭha / ye agnijihvā uta vā yajatrā āsadyāsmin barhiṣi mādayadhvam //
analyzed: viśve devāḥ śṛṇuta imam havam me ye antarikṣe yaḥ upa dyavi ṣṭha    ye agni jihvāḥ uta vā yajatrāḥ āsadya asmin barhiṣi mādayadhvam
translated: Ye who have tongues of fire, or who are Holy, sit on this sacred grass and rejoice yourselves.

original: devebhyo hi prathamaṃ yajñiyebhyo 'mṛtatvam suvasi bhāgam uttaṃam / ād id dāmānam savitar vy ūrṇuṣe 'nūcīnā jīvitā mānuṣebhyaḥ //
analyzed: devebhyaḥ hi prathamam yajñiyebhyaḥ mṛta tvam suvasi bhāgam uttaṃam    āt id dāmānam savitar vi ūrṇuṣe nūcīnā jīvitā mānuṣebhyaḥ
translated: For to the Gods, first of all, to those worthy of sacrifice, ye have granted immortality, a portion of the highest bliss. Now, O ye Savitar, unroll the thread of life for men, one after another.

original: pra vāyum acchā bṛhatī manīṣā bṛhadrayiṃ viśvavāram rathaprām / dyutadyāmā niyutaḥ patyamānaḥ kaviḥ kavim iyakṣasi prayajyo //
analyzed: pra vāyum acchā bṛhatī manīṣā bṛhat rayim viśva vāram ratha prām    dyutat yāmā niyutaḥ patyamānaḥ kaviḥ kavim iyakṣasi prayajyo
translated: The lofty hymn hath gone to Vâyu, to the God of lofty wealth, the Lord of all treasures, borne on the car,

original: indravāyū ime sutā upa prayobhir āgatam / indavo vām uśanti hi //
analyzed: indra vāyū ime sutāḥ upa prayobhiḥ āgatam   indavaḥ vām uśanti hi
translated: O Indra-Vâyu, come ye nigh to these libations with the teams,

original: mitram huve pūtadakṣaṃ varuṇaṃ ca riśādasam / dhiyaṃ ghṛtācīm sādhantā //
analyzed: mitram huve pūta dakṣam varuṇam ca riśādasam     dhiyam ghṛtācīm sādhantā
translated: I call on Mitra, Varuṇa, whose powers are pure, on him who slays the foe,

original: dasrā yuvākavaḥ sutā nāsatyā vṛktabarhiṣaḥ / ā yātam rudravartanī //
analyzed: dasrā yuvākavaḥ sutāḥ nāsatyā vṛktabarhiṣaḥ   ā yātam rudravartanī
translated: The wondrous, youthful Sons of Sudhanvan, Nâsatyas, for whom grass is strewn,

original: taṃ pratnathā / ayaṃ venaḥ //
analyzed: tam pratnathā ayam venaḥ
translated: Him as of old, this Vena,🔽If Saramâ hath found the cleft of the mountain, the great ancient path, the same as heretofore,

original: vidad yadī saramā rugṇam adrer mahi pāthaḥ pūrvyam sadhryak kaḥ / agraṃ nayat supady akṣarāṇām acchā ravaṃ prathamā jānatī gāt //
